funFacts.content: Harry Potter's wand was 11 long, made of holly, and possessed a phoenix feather core. This was described by Garrick Ollivander to be an unusual combination of wand core and wood. The feather was donated by Fawkes, Albus Dumbledore's phoenix.

Lord Voldemort's wand was 11 long, made of holly, and possessed a phoenix feather core. This was described by Garrick Ollivander to be an unusual combination of wand core and wood. The feather was donated by Fawkes, Albus Dumbledore's phoenix.
Tom Marvolo Riddle (mixing the letters it ends up being Lord Voldemort)
At the school Hogwarts there are four houses: Gryffindor, Ravenclaw, Hufflepuff and Slytherin
Harry's wand and Voldemort's wand were twins, that's why they couldn't kill each other

spells.name: Accio
spells.pronunciation: Various, including: AK-ee-oh or AK-see-oh , AK-see-oh , AS-see-oh (US), and AT-chee-oh (Anglo-Catholic pronunciation)
spells.description: Summons an object towards the caster. It is able to summon objects in direct line of sight of the caster, as well as things out of view, by calling the object aloud after the incantation (unless the spell is casted nonverbally). This spell needs thought behind it, and the object must be clear in the casters mind before trying to summon it. The caster doesn't necessarily need to know the location of the target if they say the name of the object to be summoned, such as when Hermione Granger summoned some books from Dumbledore's office simply by saying "Accio Horcrux books!" while in Gryffindor Tower.
spells.mention: Harry Potter summoned his broom to complete the first task of the Triwizard Tournament in 1994, and to summon the Portkey to escape Voldemort and the Death Eaters in the Little Hangleton Graveyard in 1995. Also, in the Battle of the Seven Potters Harry summoned Hagrid when he fell. Molly Weasley used it to get the twins' candy. The twins used it to summon their brooms from Dolores Umbridge's office
spells.etymology: The Latin word accio means "I call" or "I summon".

spells.name: Age Line
spells.description: Prevents people above or below a certain age from access to a target.

spells.name: Aguamenti
spells.description: Produces a clean, drinkable jet of water from the wand tip.
spells.mention: Used by Fleur Delacour in 1994 to extinguish her skirt, which had caught flame during a fight against a dragon. Harry used this spell twice in 1997, both on the same night; once to attempt to provide a drink for Dumbledore, then again to help douse Hagrid's hut after it was set aflame by Thorfinn Rowle, who used the Fire-Making Spell.

spells.name: Alarte Ascendare
spells.description: Shoots the target high into the air.
spells.mention: Used by Gilderoy Lockhart in 1992 to send a snake high into the air during the first and last meeting of the Duelling Club.

spells.name: Albus Dumbledore's forceful spell
spells.description: This spell was, supposedly, quite powerful as when it was cast, the opponent was forced to conjure a silver shield to deflect it.

spells.name: Alohomora
spells.description: Unlocks doors and other objects. It can also unlock doors that have been sealed with a Locking Spell, although it is possible to bewitch doors to become unaffected by this spell.
spells.mention: Used by Hermione Granger in 1991 to allow her and her friends to access the Third-floor corridor at her school, which was at the time forbidden; she used it again two years later to free Sirius's cell in her teacher's prison room.

spells.name: Amato Animo Animato Animagus
spells.description: Spell used as part of the process of becoming an Animagus. The incantation has to be recited at sunrise and sundown, every day before the consumption of the Animagus Potion. The incantation is also recited just prior to the consumption of the potion, which has to take place just after a lightning storm starts. The incantation is recited while placing the wand's tip over one's heart.

spells.name: Anapneo
spells.description: Clears the target's airway if they are choking on something.
spells.mention: Used by Horace Slughorn, cast upon Marcus Belby when the latter choked on a pheasant in 1996.

spells.name: Anteoculatia
spells.description: Causes the target to grow antlers.

spells.name: Anti-Cheating Spell
spells.description: Used to prevent cheating.

spells.name: Anti-Disapparition Jinx
spells.description: Prevents Disapparation in an area. It is used to entrap an enemy in an area.

spells.name: Anti-intruder jinx
spells.description: Prevents intruders from entering an area.

spells.name: Antonin Dolohov's curse
spells.description: An unknown curse that causes injuries that are capable of killing with enough power.

spells.name: Aparecium
spells.description: Reveals secret messages written in invisible ink, or any other hidden markings. Also works against Concealing charms
spells.mention: Used (to no avail) in 1993 by Hermione Granger to attempt to reveal any hidden writing in a diary.

spells.name: Appare Vestigium
spells.description: Reveals traces of magic, including footprints and track marks.

spells.name: Apparition
spells.description: Magically transports the caster to another location instantaneously. The destination is one that the primary user has been to or seen in some fashion previously. Can be used to apparate multiple people at once if holding each other. No incantation required.

spells.name: Aqua Eructo
spells.description: This spell is used to create, and control, a jet of clear water from the tip of the wand; it is probably related to Aguamenti.
spells.mention: Used multiple times to extinguish fires in 1994.

spells.name: Arania Exumai
spells.description: Drives away spiders, including Acromantulas.
spells.mention: Jacob's sibling used this spell to repel an Acromantula that guarded the Forest Vault in the Forbidden Forest.

spells.name: Arresto Momentum
spells.description: Decreases the velocity of a moving target. Can be used on multiple targets, as well as on the caster themselves. It was invented by Daisy Pennifold in 1711 for use on the Quaffle in Quidditch.
spells.mention: Used by Dumbledore to save one of his students from a fall in 1993; Hermione Granger used it, to little effect, in 1998 to cushion an otherwise deadly fall.

spells.name: Arrow-shooting spell
spells.description: Fires arrows from the caster's wand.

spells.name: Ascendio
spells.description: Lifts the caster high into the air. The charm also works underwater, propelling the caster above the surface.

spells.name: Avada Kedavra
spells.mention: Used by Tom Riddle to murder many of his victims without remorse.

spells.name: Avifors
spells.description: Transforms the target into a bird.
spells.mention: Taught in Transfiguration class.

spells.name: Avenseguim
spells.description: Turns an object into a tracking device.
spells.mention: In 1927, Newton Scamander used this spell to track the origins of a feather - a clue found during his search for Porpentina Goldstein - back to Yusuf Kama, whose hat the feather came from.

spells.name: Avis
spells.description: Conjures a flock of birds from the tip of the wand. When used in conjunction with Oppugno, it can be used offensively.
spells.mention: Used in 1994 by Mr Ollivander to test Viktor Krum's wand. Also employed offensively by Hermione Granger against Ron Weasley.

spells.name: Babbling Curse
spells.description: Causes uncontrollable babbling.
spells.mention: Although he was rather untrustworthy, it may not have occurred at all, but Gilderoy Lockhart says he cured a Transylvanian farmer of this affliction.

spells.name: Badgering
spells.description: Turns things into badgers

spells.name: Bat-Bogey Hex
spells.description: Transforms the target's bogeys into large bats that fly out of the victim's nose. It was invented by Miranda Goshawk.
spells.mention: Ginny Weasley was a noted practitioner of this spell, having used it at least thrice by her sixth year.

spells.name: Baubillious
spells.description: The exact effects of the spell are unknown, though it presumably is of damaging nature and it produces a bolt of white light from the tip of the wand.
spells.etymology: Currently unclear, probably from English bauble.
spells.note: This is likely the incantation for White sparks.

spells.name: Bedazzling Hex
spells.description: Allows the caster to disguise things.
spells.mention: When Xenophilius Lovegood explains the concept of how the Cloak of Invisibility is the only thing that can make a person truly invisible, he mentions that most cloaks of that kind are made with this spell.

spells.name: Bewitched Snowballs
spells.description: Causes snowballs to pelt themselves at the target.
spells.mention: Twice used by Fred and George Weasley; firstly on Professor Quirrell'shead, unwittingly striking Lord Voldemort in the face, and then again four years later to attack the windows of Gryffindor Tower.

spells.name: Bluebell Flames
spells.description: Produces magical blue flames that can be held in a jar. Not as dangerous as real fire, these magical flames can be touched, penetrated and held without it burning the holder, though it is known to singe materials such as clothing and plants.
spells.mention: This spell was a speciality of Hermione Granger's. She used it to save Harry and Ron in 1991.

spells.name: Blue sparks
spells.description: Jet of blue sparks. It can be used offensively as a minor duelling spell.
spells.mention: Following the American National Quidditch team's win at the semi-finals of the 2014 Quidditch World Cup against Liechtenstein, red, white and blue sparks filled the air so thickly it was difficult to see or breathe.

spells.name: Bombarda
spells.description: Provokes a small explosion.
spells.mention: Taught in fourth year Charms class.
spells.etymology: From the word bombard, meaning "to attack a place or person continually with bombs or other missiles".

spells.name: Bombarda Maxima
spells.description: Creates a large explosion capable of removing entire walls. A more advanced and more powerful form of the Exploding Charm.

spells.name: Brackium Emendo
spells.description: If used correctly, it is claimed that this spell will heal broken bones; this theory is supported by the etymology.
spells.mention: Used unsuccessfully by Gilderoy Lockhart on Harry Potter in 1992 after the latter's arm was broken by a Bludger; it vanished all the bones, making it resemble rubber.

spells.name: Bravery Charm
spells.description: Increases the bravery of a teammate, increasing their performance against certain foes.
spells.mention: Taught by Head of the Auror Office, Harry Potter, to members of the Statute of Secrecy Task Force, to help them address the results of the Calamity in the 2010s.

spells.name: Bridge-conjuring spell
spells.description: Conjure a bridge from thin air.
spells.mention: This spell was used by Ignotus, Antioch and Cadmus Peverell in The Tale of the Three Brothers to create a bridge over a treacherous river, a bridge upon which they met Death.

spells.name: Broom jinx
spells.description: Used to make broomsticks try to throw their riders off through a variety of means such as sudden lurches and violent swishing movements. Constant eye contact is needed for the jinx to keep working.
spells.mention: It was used by Quirinus Quirrell against Harry Potter in 1991.
spells.note: This may be related to the Hurling Hex.

spells.name: Bubble-Head Charm
spells.description: Produces a large bubble of air around the head of the user; it is commonly used as the supernatural equivalent of a breathing set.
spells.mention: Used by Cedric Diggory and Fleur Delacour in 1995; it was used the next year by many students walking through the halls, because of horrid odours made by various pranks played on Dolores Umbridge.

spells.name: Bubble-producing spell
spells.description: Produces a stream of non-bursting bubbles; there are two similar spells.
spells.mention: Used by Professor Flitwick to decorate some trees; the bubbles in this instance were golden. Used the following year by Ron Weasley when he broke his wand; these bubbles were purple.

spells.name: Calvorio
spells.description: Removes the victim's hair.
spells.mention: The book Curses and Counter-Curses by Vindictus Viridian mentions this curse.
spells.etymology: From Latin calvus = "bald".

spells.name: Cantis
spells.description: Causes the victim to burst uncontrollably into song.
spells.mention: Used by the Hogwarts professors to enchant suits of armour.
spells.etymology: Cantare is Latin for "sing".

spells.name: Capacious extremis
spells.description: Expands the internal dimensions of an object without affecting the external dimensions, enhancing its capacity, and rendering its contents lighter.
spells.mention: This spell was used by Arthur Weasley to allow eight people, six large trunks, two owls, and a rat to fit comfortably inside his modified Ford Anglia in 1992. Also on the tent in which the Weasleys, Harry and Hermione stay during the Quidditch World Cup in 1994; the tent is also used by Harry, Ron and Hermione as shelter in 1997. Also, Hermione cast this spell upon her handbag in the same year.

spells.name: Carpe Retractum
spells.description: Produces a rope of light used to pull objects towards the caster, or, if the target is fixed in place, to pull the caster towards the target.
spells.mention: Taught in third year Charms class.
spells.etymology: From the Latin carpe, meaning "to seize" and retracto, meaning "I draw back".

spells.name: Cascading Jinx
spells.description: Attacks multiple opponents in close proximity to each other.

spells.name: Caterwauling Charm
spells.description: Anyone entering the perimeter of this spell sets off a high-pitched shriek. This spell may be related to the Intruder Charm.
spells.mention: This spell was cast by the Death Eaters over Hogsmeade Wizarding Village to protect against intruders in 1998.

spells.name: Cauldron to Sieve
spells.description: Transforms cauldrons into sieves.

spells.name: Cauldron to badger
spells.description: Transforms cauldrons into badgers.
spells.note: This spell may be Badgering.

spells.name: Cave inimicum
spells.description: Produces a boundary that keeps the caster hidden from others.
spells.mention: Used multiple times by Hermione Granger in 1997 and 1998 to protect the tent she shared with Ron Weasley and Harry Potter.
spells.etymology: The incantation is a Latin phrase which translates to "beware of the enemy".

spells.name: Cheering Charm
spells.description: Makes the target feel happy. Overuse of the spell may cause the target to break into an uncontrollable laughing fit. This spell was invented by Felix Summerbee.
spells.mention: Taught to third-year charms classes, part of the written O.W.L.

spells.name: Circumrota
spells.description: Rotates objects.
spells.mention: This spell was used by Leta Lestrange to rotate a record tower in the Records Room at the French Ministry of Magic Headquarters, revealing Newton Scamander and Porpentina Goldstein to be hiding behind the tower.

spells.name: Cistem Aperio
spells.description: Opens chests and boxes.
spells.mention: This spell was used by Tom Riddle to open the chest in which Aragog was hidden.
spells.etymology: Aperio is Latin for "uncover" or "open"; Cista is Latin for "trunk" or "chest".

spells.name: Colloportus
spells.description: Locks doors and all things that can be locked. It is the counter-charm to the Unlocking Spell.
spells.mention: Used by Hermione Granger in 1996 in an attempt to prevent the Death Eaters that were following her from catching up.
spells.etymology: Perhaps a portmanteau of the Latin words colligere, which means "gather" and porta, which means "gate".
spells.note: This spell can easily be countered with Alohomora.

spells.name: Colloshoo
spells.description: Sticks the target's shoes to the ground.
spells.mention: This spell is mentioned twice, once as having been used on Severus Snape during a potions class, the other when one reads Curses and Counter-Curses by Vindictus Viridian.
spells.etymology: The suffix "shoo" is a phonetic spelling of English "shoe"; the prefix collo may come from Greek "," (pronounced "colas","cols"), which means "to glue".

spells.name: Colovaria
spells.description: Changes the target's colour.
spells.mention: The spell can be bought in Wiseacre's Wizarding Equipment in Diagon Alley. Used by fifth-years in their OWLs.
spells.etymology: Almost certainly a combination of English "colour" and "vary".

spells.name: Confringo
spells.description: Produces a fiery explosion.
spells.mention: Used by Harry Potter to destroy the side-car of a motorbike in which he was riding during a battle against some Death Eaters in 1997; it was later used by Hermione Granger in an attempt to kill Nagini and facilitate an escape from Godric's Hollow.
spells.etymology: The incantation is direct Latin for "destroy".
spells.note: This spell seems to use heat for its explosion, while Expulso uses pressure instead.

spells.name: Confundo
spells.description: Causes the victim to become confused and befuddled.
spells.mention: In 1994, Severus Snape asserted that Harry, Ron and Hermione had this charm cast on them so that they would believe Sirius Black's claim of innocence; used two years later by Hermione to allow Ron to join theGryffindor Quidditch team. It was used multiple times in 1997 and 1998.
spells.etymology: The incantation, when non-capitalised, means "I confuse"; the title may derive from the Latin confundere, meaning "to confuse" or "to perplex."

spells.name: Conjunctivitis Curse
spells.description: Causes irritation in the eyes, forcing them to swell shut. The Oculus Potion is able to counteract this curse. Dragons are particularly susceptible to this curse, as their hide makes them resistant to most spells, while their eyes remain vulnerable.
spells.mention: It was suggested by Sirius Black in his letter to Harry for him to use this spell on a dragon. Olympe Maxime used this spell on some giants in 1995.
spells.etymology: "Conjunctivitis" is the technical term for "pink eye," demonstrating its effects of irritating the eye and causing it to shut.

spells.name: Cornflake skin spell
spells.description: This spell causes the victim's skin to appear as though it was coated in cornflakes.
spells.mention: In 1996, an unnamed student went to the hospital for treatment after he was hit with it, which was done in retaliation for the Inquisitorial Squad's recent behaviour.

spells.name: Cracker Jinx
spells.description: This spell is used to conjure exploding wizard crackers; it can be used in duelling to harm the opponent, but the force of the explosion may also affect the caster.

spells.name: Cribbing Spell
spells.description: This spell, which may possibly be a charm, is used to assist the caster in cheating on written papers, tests, and exams. It is possible that these spells can negate anti-cheating spells.
spells.mention: In 1991, an unnamed Slytherin student asked his fellow students whether any of them knew any good cribbing spells.

spells.name: Crinus Muto
spells.description: Used to transfigure the colour and style of one's hair.
spells.mention: This maybe be the spell that caused Harry to turn his eyebrow yellow in 1996.

spells.name: Crucio
spells.description: Inflicts intense pain on the recipient of the curse. This curse does not physically harm the victim, but may in extreme cases drive them insane. The pain is described as having hot knives being driven into the victim. It cannot be cast successfully by a person who is doing so out of pure spite or anger; one must feel a true desire to cause the victim pain. If one casts this spell, he or she will receive a life sentence in Azkaban prison for it, as with the other twoUnforgivable Curses.
spells.mention: Infamously used by Death Eaters Bellatrix Lestrange, Rabastan Lestrange, Rodolphus Lestrange and Bartemius Crouch Junior to torture the Aurors Frank and Alice Longbottom into insanity.
spells.etymology: Latin crucio means "I torture".

spells.name: Defodio
spells.description: Allows the caster to dig and carve through the target.
spells.mention: Used by The Trio to escape from a bank in 1998 while riding a dragon. It was later used by Harry to write the epitaph for Dobby, who had been killed.
spells.etymology: The incantation is Latin for "I dig".

spells.name: Deletrius
spells.description: Counter-charm to the Reverse Spell, vanishing the image of the last spell cast. It may also disintegrate other certain images.
spells.mention: This spell was only ever seen in 1994 when Amos Diggory used Prior Incantato to detect that Winky had cast Morsmordre using Harry Potter's wand.
spells.etymology: Latin delere, meaning "to destroy", and English "detritus", meaning rubble.

spells.name: Densaugeo
spells.description: This hex causes the victim's teeth to grow rapidly, but can also be used to restore lost teeth, as proven when Ted Tonks did so in 1997 for Harry Potter.
spells.mention: Introduced in 1994, when Draco Malfoy's spell rebounded upon Hermione Granger; her teeth were past her collar before she was forced to run to the hospital to get them shrunk. Later used in 1997 to mend Harry Potter's broken teeth.
spells.etymology: From Latin dens, meaning "tooth", and augeo, meaning "I enlarge"; essentially, it means "I enlarge the tooth".

spells.name: Deprimo
spells.description: Charm used to blast holes in the ground.
spells.mention: Hermione Granger blasted a hole through the living room floor of Xenophilius Lovegood's house in 1998 using this spell.
spells.etymology: The incantation, when non-capitalised, means "to depress" or "depress".

spells.name: Depulso
spells.description: Sends the target away from the caster. It is the counter-charm to the Summoning Charm.
spells.mention: Although it is learned in the fourth-year charms classat Hogwarts, it is used multiple times in 1993, as well as in 1995.
spells.etymology: From the Latin depulsio, meaning "drive away".

spells.name: Descendo
spells.description: Causes object to fall or move downwards.
spells.mention: In 1997, it was used by Ron to magically cause the stairs in his bedroom, which lead to his family's attic, to descend; later that year, Crabbe used it in an attempt to cause a wall of rubbish behind which Ron was hiding to fall on him.
spells.etymology: Descendo is Latin for "I descend".

spells.name: Desk Into Pig
spells.description: Turns desks into pigs.
spells.mention: Professor McGonagall used this spell as a demonstration for her class of first years in 1991, then changed the pig back into a desk.

spells.name: Deterioration Hex
spells.description: Impairs foes and reduces their stamina.
spells.mention: Minerva McGonagall taught members of the Statute of Secrecy Task Force this hex to help them address the results of the Calamity in the 2010s.

spells.name: Diffindo
spells.description: Used to precisely cut or tear objects.
spells.mention: Used twice in 1994, the first time being by Harry Potter to cut Cedric Diggory's bag in order to talk to the latter, and the second time being by Ron Weasley to cut the lace from the cuffs of his dress robes in an attempt to make them seem less feminine. The spell was used a third time by Harry to swap the covers of his second-hand and brand-new copies of Advanced Potion-Making.
spells.etymology: Latin diffindere, meaning "to divide" or "to split".

spells.name: Diminuendo
spells.description: Forces the target to shrink.
spells.mention: Performed by Nigel Wolpert in 1995, during a Dumbledore's Army meeting.
spells.etymology: The incantation derives from the musical term diminuendo, meaning "a gradual decrease of the volume of sound".

spells.name: Dissendium
spells.description: Used to open passages.
spells.mention: Used multiple times in 1993 to open the statue of Gunhilda of Gorsemoor, then again four years later in a failed attempt to open Salazar Slytherin's Locket.
spells.etymology: There are numerous suggestions.
spells.note: This may not be a spell at all in the strict sense but a password; however, when used for the statue of the hump-backed witch, one must tap the statue with their wand, indicating that it is in fact a spell.

spells.name: Disillusionment Charm
spells.description: Causes the target to blend seamlessly in with its surroundings, like a chameleon.
spells.mention: Used by Alastor Moody to disguise Harry Potter in 1995.

spells.name: Draconifors
spells.description: Transforms the target into a dragon.
spells.mention: Taught in third year Transfiguration class.
spells.etymology: From the Latin word draco, meaning "dragon", and forma meaning "shape".

spells.name: Drought Charm
spells.description: Causes puddles and ponds to dry up. Though not powerful enough to drain a body of water like a lake
spells.mention: Mentioned by Ronald Weasley in 1994 when Harry was getting ready for the Second Task of The Triwizard Tournament.

spells.name: Ducklifors
spells.description: Transforms the target into a duck.
spells.etymology: From the English duck, and the Latin forma meaning "shape".

spells.name: Duro
spells.description: Turns an object to stone.
spells.mention: Used by Hermione Granger in 1998 while escaping from Death Eaters in the Battle of Hogwarts.
spells.etymology: Latin duro means "harden".

spells.name: Ears to kumquats
spells.description: This spell transforms the victim's ears into kumquats.
spells.mention: In 1995, Luna Lovegood read The Quibbler upside down in order to reveal the secret charm, written in Ancient Runes.

spells.name: Ear-shrivelling Curse
spells.description: Causes the target's ears to shrivel up.
spells.mention: Sometime between 1989 and 1994, Bill Weasley's pen-friend sent him a hat with this curse on it.

spells.name: Ebublio
spells.description: Causes the victim to inflate and explode into hundreds of bubbles; it can only be cast if an ally is using Aqua Eructo on the victim simultaneously.
spells.mention: Used often by members of the Statute of Secrecy Task Force.

spells.name: Engorgio
spells.description: Causes the target to swell in physical size. Its counter-charm is the Shrinking Charm.
spells.mention: Rubeus Hagrid used this spell on his pumpkins in 1992; two years later, Barty Crouch Jr cast this spell on a spider to make it easier for students to see when he cast a curse on it. Used on another spider three years later to test a new wand.
spells.etymology: The English word engorge means "swell".
spells.note: There is much speculation that this spell is the same as the Growth Charm, though this cannot be proven. Note that there is a difference between enlarging and engorging something, similar though they may seem.

spells.name: Engorgio Skullus
spells.description: Causes the victim's skull to swell disproportionately. This spell may be a variation of the Engorgement Charm, as they share the first word of the incantation. Its countercurse is Redactum Skullus.
spells.mention: This spell can be bought at Wiseacre's Wizarding Equipment in Diagon Alley.
spells.etymology: See etymology for above entry; "skullus" is Latin for "skull".

spells.name: Entomorphis
spells.description: This hex is used to transform the target into an insectoid for a short time.
spells.mention: Harry Potter contemplated using this hex against Dudley Dursley in 1995, though he decided against it.

spells.name: Entrail-Expelling Curse
spells.description: Expels victim's entrails. Precise effects unknown. Invented by Urquhart Rackharrow.
spells.mention: When Harry Potter visited St Mungo's Hospital for Magical Maladies and Injuries in December 1995, he saw the portrait of Urquhart Rackharrow, which mentioned his invention of this curse.

spells.name: Episkey
spells.description: Used to heal relatively minor injuries, such as broken bones and cartilage.
spells.mention: In 1996, Nymphadora Tonks used this spell to fix Harry's broken nose after Draco Malfoy broke it on the Hogwarts Express,
spells.etymology: The word comes from Greek "episkeui" (""), which means "repair".
spells.note: This is part of a family of healing spells.

spells.name: Epoximise
spells.description: Adheres one object to another, as if they had been glued together.
spells.mention: This spell is often used by students to adhere each other's belongings to their desks (or, unfortunately, their hands).
spells.etymology: Epoximise comes from the English word epoxy, which is a type of adhesive.
spells.note: This spell may be the Permanent Sticking Charm or a variation.

spells.name: Erecto
spells.description: Used to erect a tent or other upright structure.
spells.mention: Used by Hermione Granger to construct a shelter for her, Harry Potter, and Ronald Weasley in 1997.
spells.etymology: Erectum is past principle of erigere, which is Latin for "to erect".

spells.name: Evanesce
spells.description: Vanishes the target
spells.note: This and the Vanishing Spell are almost certainly the same spell.

spells.name: Evanesco
spells.description: Vanishes the target. Vanished things go "into non-being, which is to say, everything."
spells.mention: Used by William Weasley to vanish a bundle of old scrolls whilst cleaning 12 Grimmauld Place in 1995.
spells.etymology: From "evanescene", meaning "something that is fleeting or disappears.

spells.name: Everte Statum
spells.description: Throws the victim backward, similarly to being thrown.
spells.mention: Draco Malfoy used this spell on Harry Potter in 1992 during the Duelling Club.
spells.etymology: The Latin words everte, which means "to throw out" and statua, from the same language, meaning "image".

spells.name: Expecto Patronum
spells.description: This charm is a highly powerful and advanced protective spell which will conjure a spirit guardian of their positive emotions to defend against dark creatures; it can also send messages to other witches or wizards. The Patronus takes the form of an animal, unique to each person who casts it. The form of a Patronus can change when one has undergone a period of heightened emotion.
spells.mention: Taught to Harry Potter by Remus Lupin during his Anti-Dementor lessons; This is the only known spell effective against Dementors or Lethifolds.
spells.etymology: Patronus means "protector" in Latin; in archaic Latin, it means "father"; considering the form Harry's takes, this is interesting. The Latin word expecto means "I await"

spells.name: Expelliarmus
spells.description: Forces whatever an opponent is holding to fly out of their hand. It was considered to be Harry Potter's signature spell.
spells.mention: Used by Severus Snape on Gilderoy Lockhart during a live duelling demonstration during the first and last meeting of the Duelling Club in 1992.
spells.etymology: Probably a combination of Latin expello, meaning "expel", and arma, meaning "weapon".

spells.name: Expulso
spells.description: Provokes an explosion, unique in that it uses pressure to do so as opposed to heat.
spells.mention: Used by Antonin Dolohov during a fight in a cafe in 1997.
spells.etymology: From expulsum, which is past principle of expellere, which means "expel".

spells.name: Extinguishing Spell
spells.description: Puts out fires.
spells.mention: Charlie Weasley and his friends would use this spell should something go wrong in the tournament.

spells.name: False memory charm
spells.description: Implants a false memory in the victim without them realising it was not originally theirs.
spells.mention: Voldemort used this spell twice; firstly in 1943 upon his uncle Morfin Gaunt, then sometime later on the house-elf Hokey. Both instances were to hide his crimes and make the victims believe they were responsible. It is likely that Kingsley Shacklebolt used this spell on Marietta Edgecombe in 1996 in order to prevent her from revealing Dumbledore's Army to Cornelius Fudge. This is reinforced by Dumbledore stating that Shacklebolt was "remarkably quick on the uptake" in modifying her memory. It is possible that Professor Horace Slughorn used this in the next school year to hide his memory of Voldemort asking him about Horcruxes, although as he retained awareness of the true memory his spell may be a different one. It is also possible that he simply repressed it to such a degree that it could not be extracted from him against his will, as the memory he gave Dumbledore simple went blank at the right times and was replaced by a disembodied shouting, rather than images; this was noted to be crudely done. Hermione Granger used this in 1997 to make her parents believe they were named Wendell and Monica Wilkins respectively, that they have no daughter, and to make them move to Australia in order to protect them from Voldemort and his Death Eaters.

spells.name: Feather-light charm
spells.description: Makes an object light as a feather.
spells.mention: Harry Potter contemplated using this in 1993 to lighten his trunk so that he could carry it by broom to Gringotts, though he decided against it.

spells.name: Ferret to human
spells.description: Transforms a ferret into a human.
spells.mention: It was used by Minerva McGonagall on Draco Malfoy in 1994.

spells.name: Ferula
spells.description: Conjures up bandages and wraps them around a wound, splinting any broken bones.
spells.mention: Used by Remus Lupin in 1994 to bind Ronald Weasley's broken leg.
spells.etymology: Latin ferula means "walking-stick" or "splint".

spells.name: Fianto Duri
spells.description: A defensive charm which, based on the etymology, strengthens shield spells, and perhaps objects in general, in a similar way to Duro.
spells.mention: Used to protect Hogwarts School of Witchcraft and Wizardry in 1998.
spells.etymology: Latin fiant means "become" and duri means "hard".

spells.name: Fidelius Charm
spells.description: An immensely complex charm used to hide secret information within the soul of the charm's recipient, who is called a Secret-Keeper. The information is irretrievable unless the Secret-Keeper willingly chooses to reveal it, and only the aforementioned person can do so.
spells.mention: In 1993, it was explained that when Harry was merely an infant, he and his parents were hidden from Voldemort with this charm; from 1995 onward it was used to protect Grimmauld Place, and in 1998 it was used to protect Shell Cottage.
spells.etymology: Latin fidelis, which means "faithful".
spells.note: Although when a Secret-Keeper dies the secret they held can never be revealed to anyone else, in 1997 it is apparent that upon the Keeper's death all those who had been told the secret become keepers in turn.

spells.name: Fiendfyre
spells.description: Unleashes cursed fire that takes the shape of animals that actively seek out living targets and burn anything in its path, including nearly indestructable substances such as horcruxes. In addition, this fire is made even more dangerous due to the fact that it is extremely difficult to control, and cannot be extinguished with normal or enchanted water.
spells.mention: Though there are numerous instances when it may have been used, it was only proven to have been used in 1998 by Vincent Crabbe, who was killed by it.

spells.name: Finestra
spells.description: Shatters glass.
spells.mention: On 6 December 1926, Newt Scamander shattered the front window of the Voclain & Co. jewellery store in New York using this spell to try and recapture his escaped niffler when he saw it loose inside the store stealing things.

spells.name: Finite Incantatem
spells.description: Terminates all spell effects in the vicinity of the caster.
spells.mention: Severus Snape used this to restore order to the Duelling Club in 1992, after the event had descended into utter chaos.
spells.etymology: Latin finire, meaning "to finish", and incantatem.

spells.name: Finger-removing jinx
spells.description: Removes a person's fingers.
spells.mention: Gunhilda Kneen jinxed her husband with this spell.

spells.name: Firestorm
spells.description: Produces a ring of fire from the wand.
spells.mention: Albus Dumbledore used this spell to rescue Harry from Inferi in 1997.

spells.name: Flagrante Curse
spells.description: Causes objects to burn on contact.
spells.mention: The Lestrange Vault had this curse on it.

spells.name: Flagrate
spells.description: Writes in midair with firey marks.
spells.mention: Tom Riddle used this spell to write his name; Hermione Granger used it three years later to mark some doors.
spells.etymology: From the Latin flagrate, meaning "a burn".

spells.name: Flame-Freezing Charm
spells.description: Causes fire to tickle those caught in it instead of burning them.
spells.mention: Third year students wrote an essay on the use of this charm in medieval witch-burnings; Wendelin the Weird was burned forty-seven times.
spells.note: This may be the spell used in Floo Network, as well as when Albus Dumbledore set Tom Riddle's wardrobe aflame in 1938.

spells.name: Flask-conjuring spell
spells.description: Conjures a glass flask
spells.mention: On 1 May, 1998, Hermione Granger used this spell to collect the memories of a dying Severus Snape.

spells.name: Flintifors
spells.description: Transforms objects into matchboxes.
spells.mention: In the 1980s, this spell was covered in third year transfiguration classes.
spells.note: This may be related to, or the incantation for Match to needle.

spells.name: Flipendo
spells.description: Knocks objects and creatures backwards.
spells.mention: Taught in first year Defence Against the Dark Arts and Charms class.

spells.name: Flipendo Duo
spells.description: A more powerful version of Flipendo.

spells.name: Flipendo Tria
spells.description: A more powerful version of Flipendo Duo; it is said to resemble a miniature tornado.

spells.name: Flying Charm
spells.description: This spell is cast on broomsticks and flying carpets to allow them to fly.
spells.mention: Draco Malfoy mentioned this spell when insulting Ron Weasley's broomstick, wondering why anyone would charm it.

spells.name: Fumos
spells.description: Defensive smokescreen that hinders visibility.
spells.mention: This spell is covered in The Dark Forces: A Guide to Self-Protection.

spells.name: Fumos Duo
spells.description: A more powerful version of Fumos.

spells.name: Furnunculus
spells.description: Covers the target in boils (or pimples).
spells.mention: Used by Harry Potter on Gregory Goyle.
spells.etymology: Latin furnunculus, meaning "petty thief", or English furuncle, a synonym for "boil".

spells.name: Fur spell
spells.description: Causes fur to grow on the victim.
spells.mention: Fred and George Weasley used this spell on each other.

spells.name: Geminio
spells.description: Duplicates the target. When used to duplicate objects indefinitely on purpose, is known as the Gemino Curse.
spells.mention: Used by Hermione Granger on Salazar Slytherin's Locket to disguise her presence from Dolores Umbridge.
spells.etymology: The Latin word gemini means "twins".

spells.name: Glacius
spells.description: Freezes the target with icy-cold air.
spells.etymology: From Latin glacies, which means "ice".
spells.note: Not to be confused with the Freezing Charm, which merely immobilises things.

spells.name: Glacius Duo
spells.description: A more powerful version of Glacius.
spells.etymology: From Latin glacies, which means "ice".

spells.name: Glacius Tria
spells.description: A more powerful version of Glacius Duo.
spells.etymology: From Latin glacies, which means "ice".

spells.name: Glisseo
spells.description: Causes the steps on a stairway to flatten into a slide.
spells.mention: Used by Hermione Granger to escape from Death Eaters.
spells.etymology: Probably derived from French glisser, meaning "to slide".

spells.name: Green Sparks
spells.description: Jet of green sparks that can be used to signal an emergency or as a minor duelling spell.
spells.mention: Taught in Defence Against the Dark Arts; When Hagrid, Harry and Hermione try to find an injured unicorn, Hagrid says that if it is found, they must send up green sparks.
spells.note: The incantation is almost certainly Verdimillious.

spells.name: Gripping Charm
spells.description: Helps someone grip something more effectively.
spells.mention: Used on Quaffles to help Chasers carry them.

spells.name: Gytrash-conjuring spell
spells.description: Conjures luminous green Gytrashes from the wand, which can be commanded by the caster to attack an opponent.

spells.name: Hair-thickening Charm
spells.description: Thickens the victim's hair.
spells.mention: Severus Snape claimed Alicia Spinnet used this spell on her eyebrows, where as in reality she was jinxed by Miles Bletchley.

spells.name: Harmonia Nectere Passus
spells.description: Repairs a Vanishing Cabinet.
spells.mention: Used by Draco Malfoy to mend a cabinet in 1996.
spells.etymology: Latin harmonia, which means "harmony", nectere, which means "to bind", and passus, which means "step".

spells.name: Herbifors
spells.description: This spell causes flowers to sprout from the victim.

spells.name: Herbivicus
spells.description: Rapidly grows plants.
spells.mention: Taught by Professor Pomona Sprout in Herbology classes.

spells.name: Hermione Granger's jinx
spells.description: Causes a traitor to break out in boils spelling "SNEAK" on his or her forehead.
spells.mention: Hermione Granger designed and placed this jinx on the parchment signed by all members of Dumbledore's Army. When Marietta Edgecombe betrayed the D.A. to Dolores Umbridge, the jinx was triggered.
spells.note: This jinx was invented by Hermione, and may have been inspired by Furnunculus.

spells.name: Homing spell
spells.description: Offensive spells that follow their target with a constant speed after being cast.

spells.name: Homenum Revelio
spells.description: Reveals human presence in the vicinity of the caster.
spells.mention: Used multiple times by various people in 1997.
spells.etymology: Most likely from Latin homo, meaning human, and "reveal", though the classical Latin form would be hominem instead of homenum, which shows Portuguese influence ("man" is homem in Portuguese).
spells.note: It can be used non-verbally; Dumbledore does so to detect Harry underneath his Invisibility Cloak.

spells.name: Homonculous Charm
spells.description: Tracks the movements of human beings. The charm has a powerful effect in that it is not fooled by various methods of concealment and disguise, such as invisibility cloaks, the Polyjuice Potion or transformed Animagi.
spells.mention: This charm was used on Marauder's Map by James Potter, Sirius Black, Remus Lupin, and Peter Pettigrew after charting the grounds and halls of Hogwarts Castle in order to track the movements of everyone within the castle grounds.

spells.name: Homorphus Charm
spells.description: Causes an Animagus or transfigured object to assume its normal shape.
spells.mention: According to Lockhart, he used it to force the Wagga Wagga Werewolf to take its human form.
spells.etymology: Latin homo meaning "person" and Greek morphosis meaning "shaping"

spells.name: Horn tongue hex
spells.description: Transforms the target's tongue into a horn.
spells.mention: Harry Potter came across it while perusing the index of Basic Hexes for the Busy and Vexed in search of a way to overcome the dragon he knew he would have to face in the First Task of the Triwizard Tournament. He quickly ruled it out, however, realising it would only give the dragon yet another way to attack him.

spells.name: Horton-Keitch Braking Charm
spells.description: Charm patented by Basil Horton and Randolph Keitch that allows for broom-riders to stop more precisely. This spell was first used on the Comet 140 to prevent players from overshooting the goal posts and from flying off-sides.
spells.mention: Enchanted on all Comet 140 broomsticks.

spells.name: Horcrux-making spell
spells.description: This spell allows a part of a wizard's soul to pass into an object, thereby making the object a Horcrux. One has to commit murder and take advantage of the soul's "splitting apart" by this supreme act of evil in order to be able to perform this spell, and it is probably very complex. In 1943, Horace Slughorn described the spell to a young Tom Riddle as encasing a portion of the torn soul and placing it within an object. The spell itself is described in detail in a banned book known as "Secret of the Darkest Art", which Hermione Granger summoned from Albus Dumbledore's office near the end of their sixth year. According to the text, use of this spell to separate the soul will make the remaining portion of the soul very fragile, and can only be reversed by "remorse" of the wrongs the creator had made; however, the pain caused by attempting to reverse the creation of a Horcrux can destroy the individual.
spells.mention: Used by Lord Voldemort while creating his Horcruxes.

spells.name: Hot-Air Charm
spells.description: Conjures a stream of hot air
spells.mention: Used by Hermione Granger in 1995 to dry off her robes. Also used shortly after to melt snow. Also was used by Albus Dumbledore in 1997 to dry Harry's and his own robes.

spells.name: Hour-Reversal Charm
spells.description: Reverses small amounts of time (up to five hours).
spells.mention: Used to create Time-Turners, as mentioned by Professor Saul Croaker; this charm is highly unstable.

spells.name: Hover Charm
spells.description: Used to make the target hover. It is one of the many lesser variations of the Levitation Charm.
spells.mention: Used by Dobby to demolish a pudding.

spells.name: Hurling Hex
spells.description: Causes brooms to vibrate violently in the air and try to buck their rider off.
spells.mention: Professor Flitwick suggested that Harry's confiscated Firebolt may be jinxed with this spell.
spells.note: May be related to the broom jinx.

spells.name: Illegibilus
spells.description: Makes writing impossible to read.

spells.name: Immobulus
spells.description: Immobilises and stops the actions of the target. It works both on living and inanimate things.
spells.mention: Hermione used it 1992 to freeze two Cornish Pixies. Horace Slughorn used Freezing Charms todisable a Muggle Burglar Alarm.
spells.etymology: From the Latin immobilis, meaning immovable.

spells.name: Impedimenta
spells.description: Slows down or stops the target.
spells.mention: Used in 1995 when Harry was practising for the Third Task of the Triwizard Tournament. In 1996, Harry saw in a memory that James Potter used it on Severus Snape. Also used in 1997 by Harry against the Inferi and Snape. Stronger uses of this spell seem capable of blowing targets away.
spells.etymology: Latin impedimentum (plural impedimenta), "a hindrance" or "an impediment".

spells.name: Imperio
spells.description: Places the victim completely under the caster's control. The victim is put into a trance-like state, and becomes very suggestible to the commands of the caster. However, those who are strong willed may learn to resist it. One of the three "Unforgivable Curses," the use of this curse on another human results in capital punishment or life sentence in Azkaban.
spells.mention: Used on many occasions. First seen in 1994 when Barty Crouch Jr, impersonating ex-Auror Alastor Moody, used it on a spider and later on students during a "class demonstration" in a Defence Against the Dark Arts class. While breaking into Gringotts in 1998, Harry used it on a goblin and a Death Eater when they became suspicious.
spells.etymology: Latin impero, I command, and English "imperious".

spells.name: Imperturbable Charm
spells.description: Creates an invisible magical barrier on an object, such as a door. This barrier bounces objects off of it, and muffles sounds.
spells.mention: The spell was used in 1995 by Hermione to trap Rita Skeeter within a bottle while she was in beetle form. It was also used by Molly Weasley in the same year on the door of the room in which an Order of the Phoenix meeting was being held, in order to prevent her sons, Fred and George, from eavesdropping.

spells.name: Impervius
spells.description: Makes an object repel water and mist.
spells.mention: Used by Hermione Granger in 1993 on Harry's glasses while in a Quidditch match and also by the Gryffindor Quidditch team. Also used in 1997, first by Ron to protect objects in Yaxley's office from rain, and then by Hermione to protect Harry, Ron and Griphook from the burning treasure in the Lestranges' vault.
spells.etymology: It is said that the Latin impervius means (and is the source of) "impervious"; although it is the source of the word, it is better translated as impassable, as in a mountain peak.

spells.name: Inanimatus Conjurus
spells.description: It is a spell of unknown effect, most likely used to conjure an inanimate object.
spells.mention: Mentioned briefly in 1995.

spells.name: Incarcerous
spells.description: Ties up the target with ropes conjured from thin air.
spells.mention: First heard in 1996, when Dolores Umbridge tries to hold off Centaurs. Also used by Harry on the Inferi in Voldemort's Crystal Cave in 1997 and also attempted to use it on Severus Snape in the same year.
spells.etymology: Probably English incarcerate, "to imprison". Possibly linked to the Latin in carcerem, "in(to) prison".
spells.note: A non-verbal version of this spell may have been used to tie up Remus Lupin by Severus Snape during the encounter in the Shrieking Shack, and then later Peter Pettigrew in 1994. It may also have been used by Quirrell in 1992, although he is said to have merely "snapped his fingers". Also, it may have been the spell Antonin Dolohov used non-verbally to bind Ron Weasley with "shining black ropes" in a skirmish on Tottenham Court Road.

spells.name: Incendio
spells.description: Produces fire.
spells.mention: It was used in 1994 by Arthur Weasley to create a fire in the Dursleys' hearth so that he could use Floo powder there.
spells.etymology: Latin incendere, "to set fire (to)". Note that the first principal part of this verb (meaning "I set fire") is incendo, not incendio; the incantation does not match exactly any correct conjugation of the verb. Incndio, in Portuguese (same pronunciation as in English) means 'huge fire'. "Encender" in Spanish means "to ignite" and "Incendie" in French means flame. (A plausible but less likely source might be that it is a back-formation from the English word "incendiary," i.e., "causing fire.")

spells.name: Incendio Duo
spells.description: A stronger version of Incendio.

spells.name: Incendio Tria
spells.description: An improvement over both Incendio and Incendio Duo.

spells.name: Inflatus
spells.description: Inflates the target, filling it with air.
spells.etymology: The prefix 'Inflate' derives from the English verb "to expand with oxygen".

spells.name: Informous
spells.description: Informous is a spell that is used to complete one's Folio Bruti. A page with a brief description (including weaknesses and strengths) of the charmed creature is added to the caster's Folio Bruti.
spells.etymology: The prefix Info derives from the English verb "to inform".

spells.name: Instant Scalping Hex
spells.description: Instantly scalps all the hair off of a target.
spells.mention: Harry Potter came across it while browsing the index of Basic Hexes for the Busy and Vexed, trying to find a way to fight the dragon he knew he would have to face for the First Task of the Triwizard Tournament. He quickly decided it would be ineffective, because dragons do not have hair.
spells.note: This spell has similar effects to the Hair-Loss Curse.

spells.name: Intruder Charm
spells.description: Detects intruders and sounds an alarm.
spells.mention: Horace Slughorn used it on a Muggle-owned house he stayed in temporarily in 1996, but did not hear it go off when Albus Dumbledore and Harry Potter arrived, as he was in the bath.

spells.name: Locomotor Wibbly
spells.description: Causes the victim's legs to collapse as if they were turned to jelly.
spells.mention: One of the spells mentioned in Curses and Counter-Curses by Vindictus Viridian, used on Harry, practising for the Third Task of the Triwizard Tournament, by Hermione. Also, Draco Malfoy was hit with this jinx (along with another one) at the end of the term.

spells.name: Jelly-Brain Jinx
spells.description: Reduces the target's mental processes.
spells.mention: During the September 1999 riot that took place during the Puddlemere United/Holyhead Harpies Quidditch game, a lot of Harpy supporters were using this jinx.
spells.note: This spell may have been the spell that the Death Eaters hit Ron with in Harry Potter and the Order of the Phoenix in the Battle of the Department of Mysteries.

spells.name: Jelly-Fingers Curse
spells.description: Causes target's fingers to become wobbly, making it uneasy for the victim to grasp objects.
spells.mention: After a June 1999 Pride of Portree/Appleby Arrows Quidditch game, the losing Seeker accused his opposite number of putting this curse on him as they both closed in on the Snitch.

spells.name: Knee-reversal hex
spells.description: Puts knees on backward.

spells.name: Lacarnum Inflamari
spells.description: Ignites cloaks.
spells.mention: Used by Hermione in 1991 to stop Snape from cursing Harry. The incantation is only used in the film adaptation of Harry Potter and the Philosopher's Stone.
spells.etymology: Latin inflammo, or the verb inflammatio meaning "to set on fire". Lacarnum, from the Latin lacerna, meaning cloak.

spells.name: Langlock
spells.description: Sticks a victim's tongue to the roof of their mouth. Created by Severus Snape.
spells.mention: Used by Harry on Peeves and twice on Argus Filch, to general applause.
spells.etymology: Probably from the French langue ("tongue") and the English "lock".

spells.name: Lapifors
spells.description: Transforms the target into a rabbit.
spells.mention: Taught in third year Transfiguration class.
spells.etymology: From Latin lepus meaning hare, and forma meaning "shape".

spells.name: Leek Jinx
spells.description: Makes leeks sprout out of the target's ears.
spells.mention: Used by a fighting Gryffindor fourth year and sixth year Slytherin before a Quidditch match in 1992.

spells.name: Type: Charm
spells.description: Allows the caster to delve into the mind of the victim, allowing the caster to see the memories, thoughts, and emotions of the victim.
spells.mention: Used by Severus Snape on Harry after he had a dream about Arthur Weasley being attacked by Nagini in 1995. Also during Occlumency lessons in 1996. Also used non-verbally by Snape on Harry in 1997 to allow him to see where Harry had learned the Sectumsempra spell.
spells.etymology: Latin legere ("to read") and mens ("mind").

spells.name: Levicorpus
spells.description: Hoists people up into the air by their ankle. Created by Severus Snape.
spells.mention: Apparently invented by the Half-Blood Prince; it is a non-verbal-only spell (although it is whispered by Hermione in 1997). Harry Potter learnt it by reading the notes written by the Half-Blood Prince. He used it on Ron. The previous year, Harry had seen (through the Pensieve used by Severus Snape) his father, James Potter, use the spell against Professor Snape.
spells.etymology: Latin levare, "raise" and corpus, "body" or "corpse".

spells.name: Liberacorpus
spells.description: The counter-jinx to Levicorpus.
spells.mention: Harry used the spell in 1996 to counteract Levicorpus he had inadvertently cast on Ron.
spells.etymology: Latin liberare, "to free", and corpus, "body" or "corpse".
spells.note: It is not clear why Levicorpus has a specific counter-spell, and is not neutralised by simply using Finite Incantatem, although this could be due to the fact that Snape invented the spell and therefore made it irreversible except by its specific counter-curse.

spells.name: Locomotor
spells.description: Allows a witch or wizard to levitate a target a few inches off of the ground and then move said object in any given direction. Similarly to the Summoning Charm, a specific object can be moved by calling the object aloud after saying the incantation.
spells.mention: Used by Nymphadora Tonks in Harry Potter to move Harry's trunk from his room. Filius Flitwick similarly used it to move Sybill Trelawney's trunk after Dolores Umbridge sacked her. Parvati Patil and Lavender Brown used this spell to race their pencil cases around the edges of the table. A variation seen in 1998 is Piertotum Locomotor, which caused the statues of Hogwarts to be animated.
spells.etymology: Latin locus (place) and moto, "set in motion" (passive motor), or English locomotion.

spells.name: Locomotor Mortis
spells.description: Sticks legs together.
spells.mention: Used by Draco Malfoy on Neville Longbottom in 1991. Used by Harry Potter on Draco Malfoy, who deflected it, in 1996.
spells.etymology: English locomotion, "movement" + Latin mortis, "of death".
spells.note: It is unclear whether or how this spell is related to the Locomotor spell. It could, however, be that the curse "locks" any part of the body in accordance to where it is pointed, or moves the body into a position of the caster's choosing whilst placing them into an immobile state. It is possible that Draco had pointed his wand at Neville and the curse "locked" his legs together.

spells.name: Lumos
spells.description: Illuminates the tip of the caster's wand, allowing the caster to see in the dark.
spells.mention: Used by Albus Dumbledore to illuminate the dark cave in 1997.
spells.etymology: Latin lumen, "light".
spells.note: opposite incantation, Nox, puts the light out.

spells.name: Lumos Duo
spells.description: Creates a focused beam of light from the end of the wand. It is a variant of the Wand-Lighting Charm.
spells.etymology: Lumos plus Latin duo, "two".

spells.name: Lumos Maxima
spells.description: Produces a blinding flash of bright white light from the tip of the wand. It is a variant of the Wand-Lighting Charm.
spells.mention: First practised by Harry in the home of the Dursleys, then used by Dumbledore to light up the cave of the Horcrux.
spells.etymology: Lumos + maxima, Latin "greatest."

spells.name: Lumos Solem
spells.description: Produce a blinding flash of sunlight. It is a variant of the Wand-Lighting Charm.
spells.mention: Used by Hermione to free Ron from the Devil's Snare. The incantation was only used in the film adaptation of Harry Potter and the Philosopher's Stone.
spells.etymology: Derived from two words; the Latin lumen, meaning "light", and the Latin word for "sun", which in its accusative case is "solem".
spells.note: It is possible that the quality of the light is on the warmer solar end of the spectrum; Considering the known uses that the spell has been put to, it isn't that much of a stretch to presume that the spell is used to conjure Sunlight.

spells.name: Magicus Extremos
spells.description: Partnership-based charm that temporarily increases the casters' spell power.

spells.name: Melofors
spells.description: Encases the victim's head in a pumpkin.
spells.mention: Cornelius Fudge was rumoured to have been a victim of this jinx after having been overpowered by Albus Dumbledore in a duel in 1996.

spells.name: Meteolojinx Recanto
spells.description: Causes weather effects caused by jinxes to cease.
spells.mention: Suggested in 1997 by Arthur Weasley to Ron (disguised as Reginald Cattermole by use of Polyjuice Potion) as the best way to clear up the rain jinx on a Ministry office. Also used by Bartemius Crouch Jr (Disguised as Alastor Moody) In 1994 to cease the weather effect of the Great Hall's Ceiling insisting it is broken as he told Dumbledore to "Fix his ceiling".
spells.etymology: Meteorology, the study of weather, the word jinx and recant, "to withdraw or retract". Interestingly in modern English recant means to say that you no longer hold a belief.

spells.name: Mimblewimble
spells.description: Ties the target's tongue in a knot, preventing them from making coherent speech, or saying incantations correctly, making it useful in duels.
spells.mention: Seen in 1997 as a deterrent to Severus Snape, or any other unwanted visitor of 12 Grimmauld Place, from betraying their location to anyone else.

spells.name: Ministry of Magic Fog
spells.description: Patented charm used by the Ministry for Magic to conceal certain areas from Muggle view.
spells.mention: Seen in 1997 as a deterrent to Severus Snape, or any other unwanted visitor of 12 Grimmauld Place, from betraying their location to anyone else.
spells.note: In 1999, after the Invisibility Charm debacle at the Exmoor Quidditch Stadium, the Ministry considered trying this fog to hide the stadium from view.

spells.name: Mobiliarbus
spells.description: Levitates wooden objects a few inches off of the ground and moves them in any given direction.
spells.mention: In 1993, Hermione Granger used the spell to move a Christmas Tree in The Three Broomsticks beside her table to hide Harry Potter, who was in Hogsmeade illegally.
spells.etymology: Latin mobilis, "movable" or "flexible", and arbor (alternatively arbos), "tree".
spells.note: It is possible that Mobilicorpus and Mobiliarbus are variations of the same basic spell, since they share the "Mobili-" stem.

spells.name: Mobilicorpus
spells.description: Levitates and moves bodies.
spells.mention: Sirius Black used it on Severus Snape in 1994. It was probably used on Peter Pettigrew by Lord Voldemort in the graveyard to make him come forward.
spells.etymology: Latin mobilis, "movable", and corpus, "body".
spells.note: It is possible that Mobiliarbus and Mobilicorpus are variations of the same basic spell, since they share the "Mobili-" stem.

spells.name: Molliare
spells.description: Produces an invisible cushion over the target, is used primarily in the manufacturing of broomsticks.
spells.mention: Used by Hermione Granger to cushion her, Harry, and Ron's fall in Gringotts Wizard Bank in 1998.
spells.note: This spell may be related to Arresto Momentum and Spongify.

spells.name: Molly Weasley's curse
spells.description: Like the Avada Kedavra curse, it kills (or freezes) the victim. It turns the body grey/blue (or paler) while it turns to stone and then another twin jinx can blast the body into pieces.
spells.note: This may be Hardening Charm or Freezing Charm, although the latter is shown to be blue in 1992.

spells.name: Morsmordre
spells.description: Conjures the Dark Mark, which is the sign of the Death Eaters.
spells.mention: Used by Barty Crouch Jr in 1994. Also seen in 1997 over the castle to lure Albus Dumbledore to his death. It was apparently invented by Lord Voldemort.
spells.etymology: Latin mors, "death", and mordere, meaning "to bite" (or its French derivative mordre); this would appear to be associated with the name of Lord Voldemort's followers, the Death Eaters. The English murder might also contribute.
spells.note: A possible translation might be "take a bite out of death", a fitting phrase for Death Eaters.

spells.name: Mucus ad Nauseam
spells.description: Gives the victim a nasty cold and an extremely runny nose that can cause the victim to collapse if it is not treated. The cold is accompanied with constant sneezing.
spells.mention: Mentioned by Professor Quirrell to his first-year class.

spells.name: Muffliato
spells.description: Prevents others from hearing nearby conversations by filling peoples' ears with an unidentifiable buzzing.
spells.mention: It was used in 1996 by Harry Potter and Ron Weasley on various teachers and people such as Madam Pomfrey. It was created by Severus Snape. As pointed out by Hermione, it is probably not Ministry of Magic approved. It was also used in 1997 by Hermione Granger in protection of the camp-site where Harry and she stayed in hiding.
spells.etymology: English muffle, "to quiet", with a pseudo-Latin or pseudo-Italian ending.

spells.name: Multicorfors
spells.description: Multicorfors is a charm used to change the colour and style of one's clothing.
spells.mention: It may also be the same charm as when Harry accidentally changed the colour of his eyebrow, before he asked Luna to Slughorn's Christmas party. (Unlikely, as that was performed as a Transfiguration exercise, which is rather unrelated to Charms.) Could have possibly been used when Harry accidentally changed the colour of his teachers hair, at St. Grogory's Primary School.

spells.name: Mutatio Skullus
spells.description: Mutates the victim's head, causing them to grows extra heads.
spells.mention: Used by Ancient Egyptian wizards, as noted by Ron Weasley in 1993.

spells.name: Nox
spells.description: Extinguishes wandlight. It the counter-charm for the Wand-Lighting Charm, Lumos.
spells.mention: In  1994, Harry Potter and Hermione Granger used this spell to turn off their wand-lights in the Shrieking Shack.  Used in 1998 when Harry was in the passage beneath the Whomping Willow which leads to the Shrieking Shack. Lumos's power can be arranged so that a powerful wizard can make the charm illuminate intensely or to the wizards liking by loudness of incantation. For example "LUMOS!!!" would be powerful and "lumos" would be weaker. Also used by Harry Potter in 1998 to turn off the light so he could hide the Marauder's Map from Severus Snape.
spells.etymology: Latin nox,  meaning "night".

spells.name: Nebulus
spells.description: Creates fog from the tip of the wand.
spells.mention: In 1927, Albus Dumbledore used this spell to conjure a fog in London to provide concealment for his meeting with Newton Scamander.
spells.note: This may be the incantation for the Ministry of Magic Fog.

spells.name: Oculus Reparo
spells.description: Mends eyeglasses.
spells.mention: Used by Hermione in 1991 and 1992 to fix Harry's glasses.
spells.note: This spell is a variation of Reparo.

spells.name: Obliteration Charm
spells.description: Removes footprints.
spells.mention: Used by Hermione in 1995 to remove the footprints that she, Harry, and Ron left in the snow while walking to Hagrid's hut. Also used in 1997 by Hermione to remove the footprints she and Harry left behind them in the snow as they journeyed through Godric's Hollow.
spells.note: The Obliteration Charm is only known to remove footprints. There is no explanation as to what effect it can have on other things. It could possibly destroy things, according to its name.

spells.name: Obliviate
spells.description: Erases specific memories.
spells.mention: First seen in 1993 when used by Gilderoy Lockhart on Harry and Ron; the spell backfired due to a faulty wand, costing Lockhart most of his own memory. Also, Hermione Granger used this spell to wipe her parents memories in 1997. Again, it was used in 1997 when Hermione Granger used the spell on 2 Death Eaters who had followed Harry, Ron, and Hermione after their escape from Bill Weasley's and Fleur Delacour's wedding.
spells.etymology: Latin oblivisci, "forget". The spell is most often used against Muggles who have seen something of the Wizarding world.
spells.note: Invented by Mnemone Radford, who became the Ministry's first Obliviator. The Ministry of Magic employees assigned to modifying the memories of Muggles are called Obliviators. The charm can be broken by powerful magic, or extreme duress, as Lord Voldemort was able to torture Bertha Jorkins into remembering details that Barty Crouch Snr had forced her to forget using the charm. In this case, it was also shown that if the charm is too powerful, it can cause the target to develop a bad memory. This spell differs from the False Memory Charm.

spells.name: Obscuro
spells.description: Blindfolds the target.
spells.mention: Used by Hermione Granger in 1997 to obstruct the portrait of Phineas Nigellus's view of their location.
spells.etymology: English word obscure, meaning "unclear" or "unnoticeable".
spells.note: This spell might only affect characters in paintings; there are no other references to this spell.

spells.name: Oppugno
spells.description: Causes targeted objects to attack a victim. It is particularly effective in conjunction with the Bird-Conjuring Charm.
spells.mention: Used by Hermione Granger in 1996 to attack Ron Weasley with a summoned flock of canaries during an argument.
spells.etymology: Latin oppugno, "I attack".

spells.name: Orbis
spells.description: Sucks the target into the ground.
spells.etymology: Orbis is Latin for 'circle', which reflects the spell's physical appearance.

spells.name: Orchideous
spells.description: Conjures a bouquet of flowers.
spells.mention: Used in 1994 by Mr Ollivander to test Fleur Delacour's wand. Probably used non-verbally by Tom Riddle to present flowers to Mrs Smith.
spells.etymology: English orchid and Latin suffix -eous, "of or bearing (the root word)".
spells.note: A variation of this spell may have been used when Hermione Granger conjured a Christmas wreath to place on James and Lily Potter's graves in 1997.

spells.name: Oscausi
spells.description: Seal someone's mouth shut, making it appear it was never there.
spells.mention: Used by Leta Lestrange on a girl from Gryffindor when they were both in their third year at Hogwarts. The Gryffindor girl was speaking ill of Lestrange behind her back until Lestrange emerged from hiding nearby, and muted the Gryffindor girl with this spell.
spells.etymology: Possibly derived as a portmanteau of os, Latin for "mouth", and clausi (a conjugated form of claudo), Latin for "I shut". It may additionally be a pun or wordplay on scusi, the Italian interjection for "excuse me".

spells.name: Pack
spells.description: Packs luggage.
spells.mention: Used in 1994 by Remus Lupin in his office, and in 1995 by Nymphadora Tonks, once verbally and again non-verbally.

spells.name: Papyrus Reparo
spells.description: Mends torn pieces of paper.
spells.mention: This spell was used by Newton Scamander in 1927 to restore a torn postcard from Porpentina Goldstein addressed to Queenie Goldstein.
spells.note: This spell is a variation of Reparo.

spells.name: Patented Daydream Charm
spells.description: Gives the spell caster a highly-realistic 30-minute daydream. Side effects include mild drooling and a vacant expression.
spells.mention: These were invented by Fred and George Weasley and sold in 1996 at their joke shop, presumably in the form of some kind of physical object, similar to Skiving Snackboxes.

spells.name: Partis Temporus
spells.description: Creates a temporary gap in the target.
spells.mention: Used by Albus Dumbledore in the Crystal Cave in 1997. He uses it so that he and Harry can pass through the ring of fire used to ward off the Inferi.
spells.etymology: Partis is a plural form of the French verb partir, which means "to separate," "to go away," "to leave," or "to depart." Temporis is Latin for "time."

spells.name: Pepper breath hex
spells.description: Gives the victim fiery hot breath.
spells.mention: Harry Potter learned of this hex from Basic Hexes for the Busy and Vexed while researching spells to use during the Triwizard Tournament and decided not to use it against the dragon he would face in the First Task.

spells.name: Periculum
spells.description: Produces a burst of red sparks.
spells.mention: Used during the third task of the Tri-wizard Tournament by Harry.
spells.etymology: Periculum is Latin for "danger".

spells.name: Permanent Sticking Charm
spells.description: Sticks objects permanently in place.
spells.mention: First mentioned in 1995, when Sirius Black suspected that his mother's painting was fixed to the wall with such a Charm. It is implied that the portrait in the Muggle Prime Minister's office also has such a charm on it.
spells.note: It is never said whether the charm prevents the object from being removed by cutting away the section of wall. The incantation could be gluten sempra, meaning glue forever, or adher sempra, which means stick forever.

spells.name: Peskipiksi Pesternomi
spells.description: The one time it was used, it had absolutely no effect.
spells.mention: Used by Lockhart to attempt to remove Cornish Pixies.
spells.etymology: English pesky meaning "annoying", English pixie meaning "a supernatural being", English pester meaning "to annoy", English no for negative and English me for the first person pronoun.
spells.note: It is not known if the spell works or not. It also suspiciously sounds like "Pesky pixie pester no me."

spells.name: Petrificus Totalus
spells.description: Used to temporarily bind the victim's body in a position much like that of a soldier at attention; the victim will usually fall to the ground.
spells.mention: Used in 1991 by Hermione, who was trying to prevent Neville from stopping her, Ron, and Harry from leaving the common room to hunt for the Philosopher's Stone,  in the Hall of Prophecy during the Battle of the Department of Mysteries to petrify one of the Death Eaters pursuing the group, and used on Harry by Draco Malfoy in the Hogwarts Express in 1996.
spells.etymology: Latin petra, meaning "stone", and fieri (past participle factus), meaning "to become"; totalus comes from Latin "totus", meaning "complete".

spells.name: Piertotum Locomotor
spells.description: Brings animates inanimate targets.
spells.mention: In the Battle of Hogwarts, Professor McGonagall used this spell to animate the suits of armour and statues within Hogwarts, to defend the castle. Possibly used by Albus Dumbledore to enchant the statues on the fountain in the entrance to the Ministry of Magic Department.
spells.etymology: Pier means "friend" or "colleague", totum refers to "the whole" or "total", and locomotor means "the movement of".

spells.name: Piscifors
spells.description: Transforms things into fish.

spells.name: Placement Charm
spells.description: Maigcally places an object in or on a specific location. Placement Charms can be used to place a bridle on a Kelpie to render it harmless and docile.

spells.name: Point Me
spells.description: Makes the caster's wand point due north.
spells.mention: Hermione Granger taught it to Harry Potter, who used it during the Triwizard Tournament, particularly to navigate the hedge maze during the Third Task.

spells.name: Portus
spells.description: Turns an object into a portkey.
spells.mention: Used by Albus Dumbledore in 1996.
spells.etymology: Latin porta, meaning "gate", or portare, meaning "to carry" (as in to carry the caster or target to another location). There is a Latin word portus, meaning "harbour", but it is inappropriate in this context.
spells.note: Portkeys were first seen in 1994 as a means for Harry, Hermione, and the Weasleys to go to the Quidditch World Cup. However, the spell used in its creation was not seen until 1995.

spells.name: Prior Incantato
spells.description: Forces a wand to show an "echo" of the last spell it performed.
spells.mention: Used by Amos Diggory in 1994 to discover the last spell cast by Harry's wand after it was found in the hands of Winky, a house-elf.
spells.etymology: Latin prior, "previous", and incantare, "to speak a spell" (past participle incantatum).
spells.note: Can manifest in the form of the Reverse Spell effect, or Priori Incantatem, when wands with the same core attempt to do battle.

spells.name: Protean Charm
spells.description: Causes copies of an object to be remotely affected by changes made to the original.
spells.mention: First used in 1995. Hermione Granger put the charm on a number of fake Galleons. Instead of the serial number around the edge of the coin, the time and date of the next meeting of Dumbledore's Army appeared. It is possible that this charm is used on the Death Eaters' Dark Marks.
spells.etymology: The English word Protean derives from Proteus, a god in Greek Mythology. Proteus was a shape-shifter, able to take many forms. As a result, the word Protean has come to refer to versatility, flexibility, or an ability to assume many forms. "Protean" is also similar to "protein", derived from the same root, meaning a variable, flexible substance which forms strong bonds between its constituent parts.
spells.note: On Hermione's fake galleons, when the date changes, the coin becomes hot, alerting the owner to look at the coin. This may not be a feature of the original charm. It may be a Flagrante Curse, when the Protean Charm changes the coin the curse may activate. It would seem from this that you can decide what the effects on the charmed objects are. Possibly by saying something along the lines of "Protean flagrante." although this is just speculation.

spells.name: Protego
spells.description: Invisible shield that reflects spells and blocks physical entities.
spells.mention: First seen in 1995, in which Harry is taught this spell by Hermione in preparation for the third task in the Triwizard Tournament. Albus Dumbledore uses a similar spell which reverses the construction of glass back into sand when Voldemort sent shards of glass to try to stab Dumbledore. Fred and George Weasley enchanted hats they dubbed "shield hats" with this spell in 1997.
spells.etymology: Latin protego, "I cover" or "I protect".
spells.note: The original description of this spell states that it rebounds minor jinxes to the caster. However, it is shown that it can also be used to reflect or lessen the effects of more powerful spells, depending on the skill of the caster. In 1998, it is also shown to be able to create a sort of force-field across an area, and is used frequently to prevent two participants in an argument from reaching each other.

spells.name: Protego Diabolica
spells.description: Conjures a protective ring of black fire around the caster that only affects their enemies.

spells.name: Protego Horribilis
spells.description: A powerful shield charm against dark magic.
spells.mention: Cast by Professor Flitwick in an attempt to strengthen the castle's defences in the Battle of Hogwarts.
spells.etymology: Latin Protego, "I protect", and Horribilis, "horrible , frightful, dreadful".

spells.name: Protego Maxima
spells.pronunciation: pro-TAY-goh MAX-ee-Ma
spells.description: A powerful shield charm against dark magic. A stronger and bigger version of Protego, especially when combined with other wizards casting it at the same time. Was so powerful that it could also disintegrate people that came too close and tried to enter it.
spells.mention: Cast by Professor Flitwick, Professor McGonagall, Professor Slughorn and Mrs Weasley in an attempt to strengthen the castle's defences in the Battle of Hogwarts.
spells.etymology: Latin Protego, "I protect"

spells.name: Protego totalum
spells.description: Protects an area for an extended period of time.
spells.mention: In 1997, this was one of the spells used by Hermione Granger and Harry Potter to protect their camp site from unwanted visitors.
spells.etymology: Latin protego meaning "to protect" and Latin totus meaning "as a whole".

spells.name: Purple Firecrackers
spells.description: Causes purple firecrackers to shoot out from the tip of one's wand.
spells.mention: On 31 October 1991, Albus Dumbledore used this spell to get the attention of panicking diners in the Great Hall when a troll was loose in the castle.

spells.name: Pus-squirting hex
spells.description: Causes yellowish goo to squirt from one's nose.
spells.mention: Morfin Gaunt used this hex on Bob Ogden.

spells.name: Quietus
spells.description: Makes a target sound quieter. It is the counter-charm to the Amplifying Charm.
spells.mention: Used in 1994 by Ludo Bagman.
spells.etymology: Latin quietus, "calm" or "quiet".

spells.name: Redactum Skullus
spells.description: Shrinks the head of the target. It is the counter-spell to Engorgio Skullus.

spells.name: Reducio
spells.description: Makes an object shrink in size. Its counter-charm is the Engorgement Charm.
spells.mention: In 1997, Harry Potter, after checking his Blackthorn wand on the Bluebell flames with Engorgio, casts this spell to shorten the formerly enlarged flames.
