spells.etymology: English reduce, "to shrink". (Latin has a verb reducere, present tense reduco. This is the source of the English "reduce", but has a different meaning.) Also in Italian Riduco first person present tense of Ridurre, same root of Latin Reducere.
spells.note: Whether Reducio could also be used by itself rather than countering Engorgio is unknown. If it could, it would shrink normal sized items into miniature versions of themselves. References in 1992 by Arthur Weasley to "shrinking door keys" make this seem likely.

spells.name: Reducto
spells.description: Breaks objects. In stronger usages, disintegrates them.
spells.mention: In 1995, Harry used it on one of the hedges of the Triwizard maze and ends up burning a small hole in it; in 1995, Gryffindors in Harry Potter's year referenced Parvati Patil as being able to reduce a table full of Dark Detectors to ashes, and Harry and his friends later used the spell in the Department of Mysteries against the Death Eaters, shattering many Prophecy Orbs in the process; in 1997, a member of the Order of the Phoenix attempted to use this spell to break down a door which Death Eaters had blocked when the Death Eaters had cornered Dumbledore in the Lightning Struck Tower.
spells.etymology: English reduce, "to bring down;destroy".

spells.name: Refilling Charm
spells.description: Refills whatever the caster points at with the drink originally in the container.
spells.mention: Used in 1996, when Harry noticed that Hagrid and Slughorn were running out of wine.

spells.name: Reparifors
spells.description: Reverts minor magically-induced ailments, such as paralysis and poisoning.

spells.name: Reverte
spells.description: Returns objects to their original positions or states.
spells.mention: In 1927, Leta Lestrange used this spell on the record towers in the French Ministry of Magic Records Room at the French Ministry of Magic Headquarters, in an attempt to flee from pursuing Matagots. This sent all the record towers - previously summoned by Lestrange - flying backwards and spinning back into their original positions in the ground.
spells.etymology: Reverte is derived from Latin for "you shall return", being a second-person imperative form (singular, present, active) of the verb reverto ("I return, or turn back").

spells.name: Relashio
spells.description: Forces the target to release its grip on whatever it is holding.
spells.mention: Used by Harry Potter against Grindylows in the second task of the Triwizard Tournament. Also used in 1997 and 1998, when Hermione used this spell to free Mrs Cattermole from the chained chair and to free the Ukrainian Ironbelly on which they were to get out from Gringotts.
spells.etymology: Probably from the French verb relcher ="to release, to set free", or Italian rilascio (pronounced the same way as the spell)= "I release".

spells.name: Rennervate
spells.description: Awakens an unconscious victim. It is consequently the counter-charm to the Stunning Spell.
spells.mention: In 1994, Amos Diggory used it to wake up Winky and Albus Dumbledore used it to wake up Viktor Krum. Harry Potter later used it to try and reawaken a cursed Dumbledore in the seaside cave.
spells.etymology: Rennervate means "to energise.

spells.name: Reparifarge
spells.description: Used to reverse incomplete transformations.
spells.mention: Found in A Beginner's Guide to Transfiguration.

spells.name: Reparo
spells.description: Seamlessly repairs broken objects.
spells.mention: Used by Albus Dumbledore and Horace Slughorn to repair damage the latter had done to a Muggle home in Budleigh Babberton where he had been hiding.
spells.etymology: Latin reparo meaning "to renew" or "repair".
spells.note: Reparo has been seen to repair non-magical items, however it seems to have an inability at repairing magical items or items that have magic placed upon them. An example is Harry's Nimbus 2000 shown in 1993 which he is told is irreparable after it is destroyed by the Whomping Willow. Wands are also irreparable, as shown in 1992 when Ron's wand snapped after he and Harry crashed onto the Hogwarts grounds. Despite his use of Spellotape, Ron's wand malfunctioned throughout the year. Another example is in 1997 when Hermione tried to fix Harry's broken wand, which was snapped by her errant Blasting Curse. However, Harry repaired his wand with the Elder Wand. Since the Elder Wand is the most powerful wand in creation, it makes sense that it would produce the most powerful Mending Charm.

spells.name: Repello Muggletum
spells.description: Keeps Muggles away from wizarding places by causing them to remember important meetings they missed and to cause the Muggles in question to forget what they were doing.
spells.mention: It was used to keep Muggles away from the Quidditch World Cup. Hogwarts was also said to be guarded by the Muggle-Repelling Charm. It was also used by Harry and Hermione on numerous occasions, among many other spells, to protect and hide their camp site in 1997.

spells.name: Repello Inimicum
spells.description: Disintegrates the persons entering this charm.
spells.mention: This spell was used by professors Filius Flitwick and Horace Slughorn along with Order of the Phoenix member Molly Weasley to protect Hogwarts Castle in 1998.
spells.etymology: Latin "Repello", meaning "Push Back" and "inimicum", the accusative singular form of "inimcus" meaning "foe" or "enemy".

spells.name: Revelio
spells.description: Reveals secrets about a person or object.

spells.name: Rictusempra
spells.description: Tickles the target until they become weak with laughter.
spells.mention: By Harry Potter on Draco Malfoy in 1992, when they fought in the Duelling Club.
spells.etymology: Possibly the sum of two words; The Latin rictus, meaning "The expanse of an open mouth", and semper, meaning "Always". Rictus is generally used as an expression of terror, however, "always an open mouth" would, in most cases, correspond to the act of laughing uncontrollably.

spells.name: Riddikulus
spells.description: A spell used when fighting a Boggart, "Riddikulus" forces the Boggart to take the appearance of an object the caster is focusing on. Best results can be achieved if the caster is focusing on something humorous, with the desire that laughter will weaken the Boggart.
spells.mention: Taught by Remus Lupin during third year Defence Against the Dark Arts, where his students had the opportunity to practise the spell on an actual Boggart.
spells.etymology: Latin word ridiculus, "laughable" (but perhaps "absurd" or "silly" in this context).
spells.note: The effect of the spell seems to rely primarily on the state of mind of the caster. It doesn't actually change the shape of a boggart into something humorous, but rather whatever the caster is concentrating on at the moment of the casting, as when Neville was thinking of his grandmother's dress. Presumably, Mrs Weasley couldn't take her mind off of her fears for her family, so the Boggart was changed into other members of the family rather than something humorous.

spells.name: Rose Growth
spells.description: Causes rosebushes grow at an unusually fast pace.
spells.note: This spell may be related to Herbivicus.

spells.name: Rowboat spell
spells.description: Makes boats row themselves.

spells.name: Salvio Hexia
spells.description: Protects against hexes.
spells.mention: Harry and Hermione cast this spell to strengthen their camp-site's defences against intruders in 1997.
spells.etymology: Possibly derived from the Latin "salveo," meaning "to be in good health," and used as a form of greeting and farewell, and a pseudo-Latin derivative of the English word "hex"hence, "Farewell, hexes!"
spells.note: Possibly the Hex Deflection spells the fake Moody mentioned in 1994.

spells.name: Sardine hex
spells.description: Makes the victim sneeze out sardines.
spells.mention: Rubeus Hagrid once had this hex used on him.

spells.name: Sauce-making spell
spells.description: Conjures a creamy sauce from the tip of the wand.
spells.mention: Molly Weasley used this spell in August of 1994 to pour some sauce in a pot to make dinner for her family, Harry Potter and Hermione Granger.
spells.note: According to Gamp's Law of Elemental Transfiguration, food can't be conjured. This implies that sauce is not considered "good food," as things suitable for consumption may created with the spell, such as birds.

spells.name: Scorching Spell
spells.description: Produces dancing flames which presumably scorch the opponent.
spells.mention: Professor McGonagall used this spell on Professor Snape in 1998.

spells.name: Scourgify
spells.description: Cleans objects
spells.mention: First used by Nymphadora Tonks to clean Hedwig's cage in 1995. Later, Ginny Weasley performed the spell to clean up the Stinksap on the Hogwarts Express, also used by James Potter on Severus Snape after he shouted various curses and obscenities at him.
spells.etymology: Perhaps related to English scour, "clean". -ify is a common English suffix meaning "to make ...". Therefore scourgify could mean "to make clean".

spells.name: Sealant Charm
spells.description: Magically seals envelopes.
spells.mention: All applicants for wand permits in the United States were required by the Magical Congress of the United States of America to close the envelope in which they sent their applications back to the Wand Permit Office with this spell.
spells.note: This may be the parchment-sealing spell that Dolores Umbridge used in 1995.

spells.name: Sea urchin jinx
spells.description: This spell begins to transform the victim into a sea urchin.
spells.mention: This spell was used on 2 May, 1998, during the Battle of Hogwarts, by Percy Weasley on an Imperiused Pius Thicknesse.

spells.name: Sectumsempra
spells.description: Lacerates the target, as if they have been "slashed by a sword." Subsequently, the target can easily bleed to death from the wounds. This curse was invented by Severus Snape, to be used against his personal enemies.
spells.mention: Used by Harry in 1997 against Draco Malfoy, and then later against both the Inferi in Lord Voldemort's Horcrux chamber, and Snape used it against George Weasley (was unintentional; aimed for a Death Eater that tried to curse Lupin) in the Order's flight from Privet Drive. Harry learned it in Snape's old Potions textbook. In 1998, the spell is said to be Severus Snape's "signature" spell.
spells.etymology: Latin sectum, "cut", and semper, "always".
spells.note: The spell can apparently be used against any object, but was not effective when used against Inferi because they could not feel pain or bleed. The movement of the wand seems to affect how someone is cut, suggested by the erratic patterns of slashes left on Draco Malfoy's face and chest, produced by Harry Potter's wild wand-swings while using the spell against Draco. Wounds caused by this spell can be healed as proved by Severus Snape who after Harry hit Draco Malfoy with this spell he healed Draco's wounds and told him to go and get treated with dittany at once so that he would even avoid any sign of any wound. However it seems that it depends on the caster's magical abilities because Molly Weasley could not heal and restore George Weasley's ear that was cursed off by this spell.

spells.name: Shield penetration spell
spells.description: Annihilates magical enchantments and shields.
spells.mention: Used by Voldemort to break the enchantments placed around Hogwarts School of Witchcraft and Wizardry in 1998 by Filius Flitwick, Minerva McGonagall, and Molly Weasley.

spells.name: Shooting Spell
spells.description: Used to shoot objects
spells.mention: This spell was used by Harry Potter and Ronald Weasley in 1997 on their Horcrux hunt in an attempt to catch a rabbit for food.

spells.name: Smashing spell
spells.description: Produces explosions

spells.name: Serpensortia
spells.description: Conjures a serpent from the caster's wand.
spells.mention: Used by Draco Malfoy while duelling Harry Potter in 1992.
spells.etymology: Latin serpens meaning "a snake" and Latin ortis meaning "source".

spells.name: Silencio
spells.description: Makes something silent.
spells.mention: First used by Hermione in 1996 to silence a frog and a raven in Charms class, then later used to silence a Death Eater that was trying to tell his comrades where they were.
spells.etymology: Probably Latin silentium, "silence". Also, silencio and silncio (which is closer to the English pronunciation) mean "silence" in Spanish and Portuguese, respectively.

spells.name: Skurge
spells.description: Cleans up ectoplasm and frightens ghosts and other spirits.
spells.mention: Taught in second year Charms class.

spells.name: Slippery Jinx
spells.description: Makes an object slippery and difficult to hold.
spells.mention: Mentioned in Harry Potter: Hogwarts Mystery

spells.name: Slugulus Eructo
spells.description: Forces the victim to burp up slimy slugs.
spells.mention: In 1992, Ronald Weasley attempted to curse Draco Malfoy with this spell after the latter insulted Hermione Granger, but was unsuccessful as his wand at the time was broken, and thus his curse backfired on himself.

spells.name: Sonorous Charm
spells.description: This charm emits a magnified roar from the tip of the wand. This noise disrupts all in its path, and can even be used to harm opponents.
spells.note: Not to be confused with the Amplifying Charm, Sonorus.

spells.name: Sonorus
spells.description: Makes the target sound louder. The counter-charm is the Quietening Charm, Quietus.
spells.mention: By Ludo Bagman in 1994 at the beginning of the Quidditch World Cup and by Albus Dumbledore several times in the Triwizard Championship. Used by Lord Voldemort several times during the Battle of Hogwarts in 1998.
spells.etymology: Latin sonorus, "loud; noisy".

spells.name: Specialis Revelio
spells.description: Reveals spells cast on objects or potions.
spells.mention: Used by Hermione Granger to find out more of Harry's Advanced Potion-Making book in 1996. Used by Ernie Macmillan to find out ingredients of a potion.
spells.etymology: Latin specialis, "particular;individual" and revelare (present tense revelo), "unveil".
spells.note: In 1994, Severus Snape cast a similar spell, but with different words ("Reveal your secrets!"), on the Marauder's Map, though he may have just been saying those words as he cast the spell non-verbally.

spells.name: Sponge-Knees Curse
spells.description: Makes the target's legs spongy, making it difficult for them to walk.
spells.mention: Used during the September 1999 riot that took place at a Puddlemere vs. Holyhead Harpies match. The Puddlemere supporters used this curse against the Holyhead Harpies supporters in retaliation to the Jelly-Brain Jinx.
spells.note: This spell is similar in effect to the Jelly-Legs Curse.

spells.name: Spongify
spells.description: Softens objects, making them rubbery and bouncy.
spells.mention: This charm is found in The Standard Book of Spells, Grade 1.

spells.name: Squiggle Quill
spells.description: Transforms writing quills into worms.
spells.note: This spell may be Vermiculus.

spells.name: Stealth Sensoring Spell
spells.description: Detects those under magical disguise.
spells.mention: In 1996, Professor Umbridge cast this around her office.

spells.name: Steleus
spells.description: A hex that causes the victim to sneeze for a short period of time. This spell is used in duelling to distract the opponent.
spells.etymology: Steleus derives from the Latin sternuo, meaning I sneeze.

spells.name: Stinging Jinx
spells.description: Stings the flesh of a target. This spell is also known as
spells.mention: Harry Potter inadvertently used one on Severus Snape during Occlumency lessons in 1996. It was non-debilitating in that instance, but it is stronger when intentionally cast, as shown by the results of Hermione Granger's Stinging Hex used on Harry Potter in 1998 to purposefully distort Harry's appearance.
spells.note: Also known as the Stinging Hex.

spells.name: Stretching Jinx
spells.description: Stretches the target.
spells.mention: Molly Weasley remarked in 1996 that recent growth spurts had made her son Ron and his friend, Harry Potter, look as if this jinx had been cast upon them both.

spells.name: Stupefy
spells.description: Stuns the target, rendering them unconscious.
spells.mention: Often; particularly by a number of wizards and witches (including Dolores Umbridge) against Minerva McGonagall in 1996. It's also taught by Harry in his D.A. meetings.
spells.etymology: English stupefy, which means 'to put into a stupor', a temporary vegetative state.
spells.note: The physical manifestation of the spell is a beam of red light emanating from the caster's wand. The spell wears off after a short time, and can be countered by Rennervate. Nearly useless on magic-resistant creatures such as dragons, trolls and giants unless more than one Stupefy spell is used at the same time. The force of the spell is additive or perhaps even exponential, and it can cause severe injury if many spells are used on a target that is not normally resistant to its effects. Hagrid, as a half-giant, was impervious to this spell - or at least, a lone one.

spells.name: Supersensory Charm
spells.description: Grants the caster to have enhanced senses, or to be able to sense things they would not normally sense.
spells.mention: Mentioned by Ron outside of the Hogwarts Express in 2017 as a potential substitute for using mirrors while driving a Muggle auto mobile.

spells.name: Surgito
spells.description: Counter-charm that can be used to remove enchantments.
spells.mention: In 1927, Newton Scamander used Surgito to lift an enchantment that was placed on Jacob Kowalski. As a result of the spell, Kowalski awoke from the dreamlike enchanted state, and regained an awareness of reality in the present.
spells.etymology: Surgito is a Latin word in the imperative form meaning "you/he/she shall arise, or get up", and is a conjugation of the verb surgo ("I arise"). The etymology is appropriate, considering that the effects of the spell on Jacob Kowalski can be likened to waking up from a confused, dreamlike state.

spells.name: Switching Spell
spells.description: Switches two targets simultaneously.
spells.mention: Harry contemplated using this spell against his dragon in the first task of the Triwizard Tournament. ((He considered swapping its fangs for wine gums)). Neville Longbottom misuses the spell, transplanting his ears onto a cactus.

spells.name: Taboo
spells.description: A jinx which may be placed upon a word or a name, so that whenever that word is spoken, a magical disturbance is created which alerts the caster of the Taboo to the location of the speaker. Any protective enchantments in effect around the speaker are broken when the Tabooed word is spoken aloud.
spells.mention: This curse was placed on the word "Voldemort"; Harry, Ron and Hermione are tracked this way to Tottenham Court Road. Ron tells the other two to stop using the word as he began to fear the name might be a curse, later discovering it to be a Taboo. Later, Harry accidentally says Voldemort's name again, resulting in the trio being caught by Death Eaters and taken to Malfoy Manor.

spells.name: Tail-growing hex
spells.description: Causes the victim to grow a tail.
spells.mention: When Miranda Goshawk had her Book of Spells printed, she gave copies to her sisters that had various misprints in them; one such misprint somehow gave her sister Romilda a tail. Timothy Blenkinsop was hit with this hex when he was caught in the crossfire of a Puddlemere United vs. Holyhead Harpies riot.

spells.name: Tarantallegra
spells.description: Makes a target's legs spasm wildly out of control, making it appear as though they are dancing.
spells.mention: First used by Draco Malfoy on Harry Potter in the Duelling Club in 1992.
spells.etymology: Italian tarantella, a kind of fast country dance once popular in parts of Italy, supposedly from the frantic motion caused by the bite of a tarantula; and allegro, a musical term meaning "quick".

spells.name: Teacup to tortoise
spells.description: Transforms a teacup into a tortoise.
spells.mention: Seen on the Scholastic Harry Potter Official Site.
spells.note: May be related to the Teapot to tortoise spell covered in the third year at Hogwarts School of Witchcraft and Wizardry.

spells.name: Teapot to tortoise
spells.description: Transforms a teapot into a tortoise.
spells.mention: Third years at Hogwarts School of Witchcraft and Wizardry were required to cast the spell during their final exams.
spells.note: May be related to the teapot to Teacup to tortoise spell.

spells.name: Teeth-straightening spell
spells.description: Straightens crooked teeth.
spells.mention: Sir Nicholas de Mimsy-Porpington attempted to use this spell on Lady Grieve at her request, but failed and gave her a tusk instead. He was executed the following morning. After he returned as a ghost, Nearly-Headless Nick recounted the incident in a ballad.

spells.name: Teleportation Spell
spells.description: Vanishes objects which then appear elsewhere.
spells.mention: In 1996, Albus Dumbledore  used this to transport Harry Potter's school supplies, clothes, and owl to the Burrow.

spells.name: Tentaclifors
spells.description: Transfigures the target's head into a tentacle.

spells.name: Tergeo
spells.description: Siphons liquid and cleans objects.
spells.mention: Hermione Granger used the spell in 1996 to remove blood from Harry's face. It is later used to remove spilled ink from parchment. It was also used in 1997 to clean off a handkerchief by Ron and to dust off a picture of Gellert Grindelwald in Bathilda Bagshot's house by Harry Potter.
spells.etymology: Latin tergere, "wipe off; cleanse".

spells.name: Titillando
spells.description: Tickles and weakens the victim.

spells.name: Toenail-growing hex
spells.description: Causes the toenails to grow at an extreme and uncontrollable rate.
spells.mention: In 1996, Harry used this to much applause from classmates, on Vincent Crabbe.
spells.note: This is a hex that is probably not approved by the Ministry of Magic, as it was invented by Severus Snape.

spells.name: Transmogrifian Torture
spells.description: Tortures the victim to death.
spells.mention: Gilderoy Lockhart suggested that it was this curse that "killed" Mrs Norris after she was really found petrified on a torch bracket.
spells.etymology: English "transmogrify", meaning "to change or alter greatly, often to grotesque effect", possibly implying that the curse changes the shape of the victim to cause pain.
spells.note: The incantation to this curse is possibly Transmogrify.

spells.name: Trip Jinx
spells.description: Forces the target to trip and fall over.
spells.mention: Seen in 1996. It was cast successfully on Harry Potter by Draco Malfoy, when he and other members of the Inquisitorial Squad attempted to round up members of Dumbledore's Army.

spells.name: Twitchy-Ears Hex
spells.description: Causes the victim's ears to twitch.
spells.mention: Miranda Goshawk recommended this hex to be cast on somebody practising the Shield Charm.
spells.note: . During the fourth year Hex-deflection test for Defence Against the Dark Arts, Harry Potter was hexed with this spell by Bartemius Crouch Junior (then disguised as Alastor Moody).

spells.name: Unbreakable Charm
spells.description: Makes objects unbreakable.
spells.mention: Hermione Granger used the charm on a jar, in which she put Rita Skeeter in her Animagus beetle form to prevent her from transforming back into a human.

spells.name: Unbreakable Vow
spells.description: Causes a vow taken by a witch or wizard to be inviolable; if they should break it, the consequence is death.
spells.mention: Snape made an Unbreakable Vow with Narcissa Malfoy at the beginning of Half-Blood Prince, vowing to help Narcissa's son Draco with a task given to him by Voldemort, and to finish the task should Draco prove incapable. Fred and George attempted to force an Unbreakable Vow upon Ron as children. According to Ron, it causes death when the vow is broken.

spells.name: Unsupported flight
spells.description: Allows a witch or wizard to fly through the air unaided. Technique invented by Lord Voldemort
spells.mention: Demonstrated by Tom Riddle during the Battle of the Seven Potters, and by Severus Snape before his ousting.

spells.name: Vacuum cleaner spell
spells.description: Cleans objects by using the wand to suck up dust like a vacuum cleaner.
spells.mention: Used by Madam Malkin in 1996.

spells.name: Ventus
spells.description: Shoots a jet of strong spiralling wind from the tip of the wand.
spells.mention: Used by Newton Scamander to send away Stebbins on a London street, much to the bemusement of passing Muggles.
spells.etymology: Ventus is a Latin word, meaning "wind".

spells.name: Ventus Duo
spells.description: A stronger version of the Ventus Jinx

spells.name: Vera Verto
spells.description: Turn animals to water goblets.
spells.mention: Taught by Minerva McGonagall in her Transfiguration class. Also used by Ronald Weasley unsuccessfully in one of her second year classes thanks to his damaged wand.
spells.etymology: From Latin vera meaning "right" or "proper", and verto, meaning I turn.

spells.name: Verdillious
spells.description: A spell used to shoot green sparks from the end of the wand.

spells.name: Verdimillious
spells.description: Produces a jet of green sparks that can be used in duelling, or to reveal things hidden by dark magic.
spells.mention: Taught in first year Defence Against the Dark Arts teacher's office class.
spells.note: This spell is almost certainly the incantation for Green Sparks.

spells.name: Verdimillious Duo
spells.description: A more powerful version of Verdimillious.
spells.mention: Learned in first year Defence Against the Dark Arts.

spells.name: Vermiculus
spells.description: Transforms things into worms.
spells.mention: Appeared in Harry Potter and the Goblet of Fire (video game).
spells.note: This spell may have some connection with Squiggle Quill.

spells.name: Vermillious
spells.description: Jet of red sparks that can be used to signal an emergency or as a minor duelling spell.

spells.name: Vipera Evanesca
spells.description: Vanishes snakes. Subsequently, it is the counter-spell for the Snake Summons Spell.
spells.mention: Severus Snape cast this spell in 1992 at the Duelling Club to vanish a snake that Draco Malfoy had conjured while duelling Harry Potter.
spells.etymology: Vipera is a genus of venomous vipers, a type of snake. Evanesca likely shares its origin with Evanesco, which means "disappear" in Latin.

spells.name: Vulnera Sanentur
spells.description: Healing spell that slows blood flow, clears residue, and knits wounds. It is the counter-curse to Sectumsempra.
spells.mention: Used by Severus Snape to heal the wounds of Draco Malfoy caused by the Sectumsempra curse cast by Harry Potter in 1997.
spells.etymology: Vulnera Sanentur derives from the Latin vulnus, "wound,"

spells.name: Waddiwasi
spells.description: Used to shoot small, soft masses of whatever the caster so desires at the target
spells.mention: Cast by Remus Lupin in 1993, on Peeves the Poltergeist, sending a wad of chewing gum up his nose.
spells.etymology: "Waddiwasi" comes from two words. "Vadd" and "vas-y". "Vadd" is a Swedish word that can mean "wadding" and "vas-y" is French term that means "go ahead" or "Come on!" Together, they can roughly mean "The wad goes ahead."
spells.note: This spell may be related to the Oppugno Jinx.

spells.name: Washing up spell
spells.description: Enchanted dirty dishes to wash themselves.
spells.mention: It was used non-verbally by Molly Weasley after preparing breakfast for Harry Potter upon his arrival to The Burrow on 4 August, 1992.

spells.name: Wingardium Leviosa
spells.description: Makes objects fly, or levitate.
spells.mention: This spell is taught in early first-year charms classes; this came into good use later in that year, when Ron Weasley performed the spell to knock out a mountain troll; six years later, Harry uses the charm to levitate the side-car of his godfather's flying motorbike; Ron used it again this year to make a twig poke a tree.
spells.etymology: "Wingardium" almost certainly contains English wing, meaning "fly". "Leviosa" probably originates from Latin levis, meaning "light".

potions.name: Ageing Potion
potions.description: A potion that, depending on the amount taken, ages the drinker to various ages.

potions.name: Alihotsy Draught
potions.description: A potion from the Alihotsy plant; causes hysterical laughter.

potions.name: Amortentia
potions.description: The world's strongest Love Potion; does not create real love, just powerful obsession.

potions.name: Angel's Trumpet Draught
potions.description: Effects and usage of this potion are unknown.

potions.name: Anti-Paralysis Potion
potions.description: A potion that heals paralysis.

potions.name: Antidote to Common Poisons
potions.description: A potion that reverses the effects of common poisons. Contains Bezoar, Mistletoe Berries, and Unicorn Horns.

potions.name: Antidote to Uncommon Poisons
potions.description: A potion that reverses the effects of uncommon poisons.

potions.name: Antidote to Veritaserum
potions.description: A potion that removes the effects of Veritaserum.

potions.name: Armadillo Bile Mixture
potions.description: Unknown

potions.name: Babbling Beverage
potions.description: A potion that causes uncontrollable speaking of nonsense.

potions.name: Baneberry Potion
potions.description: A poisonous brew of unknown exact effect.

potions.name: Baruffio's Brain Elixir
potions.description: A potion that apparently increases the taker's brain power.

potions.name: Beautification Potion
potions.description: A potion that makes the taker very beautiful.

potions.name: Befuddlement Draught
potions.description: A potion that makes the taker confused and reckless.

potions.name: Beguiling Bubbles
potions.description: A Love Potion sold at Weasleys' Wizard Wheezes.

potions.name: Black Fire Potion
potions.description: A potion that makes the taker able to move through black fire uninjured.

potions.name: Blemish Blitzer
potions.description: A potion that most likely gets rid of acne.

potions.name: Blood-Replenishing Potion
potions.description: A potion that replenishes the taker's blood if they have been injured and lost blood.

potions.name: Bloodroot Poison
potions.description: A poisonous potion.

potions.name: Bruise removal paste
potions.description: A paste invented by Fred and George Weasley to remove bruises.

potions.name: Bulgeye Potion
potions.description: Presumed to make the taker's eyes swell.

potions.name: Bundimun Pomade
potions.description: A potion that is presumably a hair pomade containing Bundimun secretion.

potions.name: Bundimun Secretion
potions.description: A magical substance that, when diluted, is known to be used in some magical cleaning products.

potions.name: Burn-Healing Paste
potions.description: A thick paste used to heal burns.

potions.name: Burning Bitterroot Balm
potions.description: Presumably a soothing balsam made from the Bitterroot plant.

potions.name: Calming Draught
potions.description: A potion that calms the user of shock, trauma, etc.

potions.name: Caxambu Style Borborygmus Potion
potions.description: Provokes stomach growling

potions.name: Cheese-Based Potions
potions.description: Potions whose main ingredients are cheese.

potions.name: Chelidonium Miniscula
potions.description: The effects of this potion are unknown.

potions.name: Confusing Concoction
potions.description: A potion that confuses the taker.

potions.name: Cough Potion
potions.description: A potion that soothes and reduces coughs.

potions.name: Cupid Crystals
potions.description: A Love Potion sold at Weasleys' Wizard Wheezes.

potions.name: Cure for Boils
potions.description: A potion that cures boils. Seen/Mentioned:Taught to first years in Potions class.

potions.name: Dawdle Draught
potions.description: Helps the drinker deal with traces.

potions.name: Death potion
potions.description: Kills those who come into contact with it

potions.name: Death-Cap Draught
potions.description: Effects of this potion are unknown, but it is possibly a poison.

potions.name: Deflating Draught
potions.description: A potion that deflates anything swollen by magical means.

potions.name: Developing Solution
potions.description: A potion used in the developing of magical photographs, making them move.

potions.name: Dizziness Draught
potions.description: A potion that makes the taker dizzy and lightheaded.

potions.name: Dogbane Potion
potions.description: The effects of this potion are unknown, but it is possibly poisonous to dogs.

potions.name: Dogbreath Potion
potions.description: Gives the drinker a fiery breath. Has a purple hue

potions.name: Doxycide
potions.description: A solution that kills Doxys

potions.name: Dr Ubbly's Oblivious Unction
potions.description: Heals wounds given by thoughts.

potions.name: Dragon Poison
potions.description: A poisonous potion most likely taken from dragons.

potions.name: Dragon Tonic
potions.description: A tonic used to heal sickly dragons.

potions.name: Dragon dung fertiliser
potions.description: A solution that helps plants grow.

potions.name: Draught of Living Death
potions.description: A potion that places the taker in a state of sleep that makes them seem like they are dead. Seen/Mentioned: Severus Snape asked a question related to this potion to Harry in 1991; Horace Slughorn showed it to 6th years in 1996.

potions.name: Draught of Peace
potions.description: A potion that relieves anxiety.

potions.name: Dreamless Sleep Potion
potions.description: A potion that places the taker in a sleep that is dreamless.

potions.name: Drink of Despair
potions.description: A potion that puts the taker in extreme pain.

potions.name: Drowsiness Draught
potions.description: Makes drinker drowsy

potions.name: Elixir of Life
potions.description: A potion created from the Philosopher's Stone that extend the taker's life. Seen/Mentioned:Hermione Granger told Harry and Ron about this in 1991. Nicolas Flamel and his wife are known to be using it and they lived upto more that 600 years.

potions.name: Elixir to Induce Euphoria
potions.description: A potion that induces a sense of inexplicable, irrational happiness upon the drinker.

potions.name: Erumpent Potion
potions.description: A potion that is highly explosive when it touches or is touched by an outside source.

potions.name: Everklena
potions.description: A supposed cleaning product that in reality caused grime to spawn.

potions.name: Essence of Insanity
potions.description: A potion which presumably causes irrational behaviour, possibly inflicting the condition of insanity. Seen/Mentioned:Ronald Weasley and Hermione Granger thought Harry had accidentally consumed it, due to his strange behaviour after consuming the Felix Felicis.

potions.name: Everlasting Elixirs
potions.description: A potion with the effect to either never run out of potion or to work forever.

potions.name: Exploding Potion
potions.description: A very volatile potion, and when completed, can be used to create explosions.

potions.name: Exstimulo Potion
potions.description: Boosts the spell power of the drinker.

potions.name: Fake Protective Potions
potions.description: A potion that claimed to protect the taker from Dark magic, but did not.

potions.name: Fatiguing Infusion
potions.description: A potion that, when either drank or inhaled, caused fatigue.

potions.name: Felix Felicis (Also known as Liquid Luck)
potions.description: A magical potion that makes the taker successful in all their endeavours.

potions.name: Fergus Fungal Budge
potions.description: A fungicidal product that treated ringworm infections on the feet.

potions.name: Fire Protection Potion
potions.description: A potion that protects the taker from being burnt.

potions.name: Flesh-Eating Slug Repellent
potions.description: A pesticide that repels flesh-eating slugs.

potions.name: Forgetfulness Potion
potions.description: A potion that makes the taker forgetful.

potions.name: Frog Parts Mixture
potions.description: A packet of potion ingredients that most likely contained frog parts.

potions.name: Fungiface Potion
potions.description: A potion that makes the taker's face break out in fungi.

potions.name: Garrotting Gas
potions.description: A gas that induces choking and possibly suffocates the taker.

potions.name: Girding Potion
potions.description: A potion that gives the taker extra endurance.

potions.name: Grand Pepperup Potion
potions.description: A stronger version of Pepperup Potion.

books.title: Harry Potter and the Sorcerer's Stone
books.author: J. K. Rowling
books.description: On his birthday, Harry Potter discovers that he is the son of two well-known wizards, from whom he has inherited magical powers. He must attend a famous school of magic and sorcery, where he establishes a friendship with two young men who will become his companions on his adventure. During his first year at Hogwarts, he discovers that a malevolent and powerful wizard named Voldemort is in search of a philosopher's stone that prolongs the life of its owner.

books.title: Harry Potter and the chamber of secrets
books.author: J. K. Rowling
books.description: Harry Potter and the sophomores investigate a malevolent threat to their Hogwarts classmates, a menacing beast that hides within the castle.

books.title: Harry Potter and the Prisoner of Azkaban
books.author: J. K. Rowling
books.description: Harry's third year of studies at Hogwarts is threatened by Sirius Black's escape from Azkaban prison. Apparently, it is a dangerous wizard who was an accomplice of Lord Voldemort and who will try to take revenge on Harry Potter.

books.title: Harry Potter and the Goblet of Fire
books.author: J. K. Rowling
books.description: Hogwarts prepares for the Triwizard Tournament, in which three schools of wizardry will compete. To everyone's surprise, Harry Potter is chosen to participate in the competition, in which he must fight dragons, enter the water and face his greatest fears.

books.title: Harry Potter and the Order of the Phoenix
books.author: J. K. Rowling
books.description: In his fifth year at Hogwarts, Harry discovers that many members of the wizarding community do not know the truth about his encounter with Lord Voldemort. Cornelius Fudge, Minister of Magic, appoints Dolores Umbridge as Defense Against the Dark Arts teacher because he believes that Professor Dumbledore plans to take over her job. But his teachings are inadequate, so Harry prepares the students to defend the school against evil.

books.title: Harry Potter and the Half-Blood Prince
books.author: J. K. Rowling
books.description: Harry discovers a powerful book and, while trying to discover its origins, collaborates with Dumbledore in the search for a series of magical objects that will aid in the destruction of Lord Voldemort.

books.title: Harry Potter and the Deathly Hallows
books.author: J. K. Rowling
books.description: Harry, Ron and Hermione go on a dangerous mission to locate and destroy the secret of Voldemort's immortality and destruction - the Horcruces. Alone, without the guidance of their teachers or the protection of Professor Dumbledore, the three friends must lean on each other more than ever. But there are Dark Forces in between that threaten to tear them apart. Harry Potter is getting closer and closer to the task for which he has been preparing since the first day he set foot in Hogwarts: the last battle with Voldemort.

books.title: Harry Potter and the Cursed Child
books.author: J. K. Rowling
books.description: Harry's second son entered Hogwarts, but in Slytherin. His relationship with Harry is getting worse and he became close friends with Draco's son, Scorpius Malfoy who is said to be Lord Voldemort's son.
